 1. THE SECTOR A. SECTORAL HISTORY AND CONDITIONS Country Background I. I After several decades of war and disunity, Viet Nam was unified under socialism in 1975. In 1989, Government launched a successful program of adjustment and reform ("Doi Moi"), with the aim of achieving macroeconomic structural reform, liberalization and stabilization Structural reforms included the decollectivization of agriculture, liberalization of prices and foreign trade, and contraction of state enterprises and subsidies. Under this program, real annual GDP growth has averaged 7 percent, inflation rates and the fiscal deficit have been substantially reduced, and exports have grown by more than 30 percent per annum to become a leading sector in the economy. Prospects for the coming decade are bright. 1.2 Viet Nam also continues to benefit from many positive legacies of the decades of socialist rule. The distribution of consumption is relatively equal by comparison with other countries, and an impressive network of basic social services has been put in place over the past three decades. As a result, 88 percent of all adults are literate, including 84 percent of adult women, while 78 percent of children aged 6-10 years are enrolled in primary school. Life expectancy is currently estimated at around 67 years and infant mortality at around 40 per 1,000 live births. More than 94 percent of children survive their first five years of life. 1.3 However, Viet Nam still remains one of the poorest countries in the world, with a per capita income estimated at under US$200. About one quarter of the population is too poor to afford an adequate daily basic food intake, and more than half of all young children are stunted. Between 40 and 50 percent of the population are below a poverty line that includes expenses for both food and non-food basic needs. Though the adjustment and reform program provided much more broadly-based benefits than in other transition economies because of the dominant role of family-based agriculture, and though its social costs have been relatively mild, the poorest groups are still disadvantaged and likely to lag behind without continuing special attention. A combination of broad-based economic growth with continued access for the poor to basic social services will be essential for long-term national economic development and poverty reduction. 1.4 Reduction of population growth will make a vital contribution to both economic growth and poverty alleviation. Viet Nam's population now stands at around 73 million, a 35 percent increase over the 54 million enumerated in the census of 1979 shortly after reunification. Pressure on the country's agricultural and forest land is acute. Despite recent falls in fertility, the population is still growing at over 2 percent per annum, due to a
 - 2 - combination of extremely low mortality with the large cohorts in the young reproductive ages resulting from past high fertility. If this rate of growth were maintained, the population would double within the next 33 years. Dependency ratios are also still high, resulting in heavy costs in education and child health care relative to productive capacity. Fertility urgently needs to be reduced to replacement level and maintained there if Viet Nam's productive potential is to be maximized. 1.5 Viet Nam's development strategy is directed at five specific objectives: (1) to maintain macroeconomic stability; (2) to make a steady transition to an open market economy; (3) to improve basic infrastructure; (4) to alleviate poverty and reduce regional inequalities; (5) to preserve the nation's natural resource base so that economic achievements can be sustained over the long term. Development of the population and health sectors is closely linked to the objectives of poverty alleviation, reduction of regional inequalities and natural resource sustainability. Sector History and Status 1.6 Health Status. Viet Nam has achieved an extraordinarily low level of mortality for its income and stage of development. Nevertheless, its main health problems remain those common to most developing countries. Infectious and parasitic diseases, particularly TB, malaria and acute respiratory infections (ARIs), are still a substantial threat to the population at large. Among children, the communicable diseases of childhood have declined rapidly in incidence and severity following the success of the Expanded Program of Immunization (EPI), but ARIs and diarrheal diseases are still major killers of children and constitute their most important health problems. Nearly 60 percent of infant deaths are due to these two groups of diseases. Severe and acute child malnutrition is now very uncommon, but chronic undernutrition manifested as stunting is still the fate of the majority. Among infants, prematurity, low birthweight and problems in delivery are also major causes of death and ill-health. For women, pregnancy and delivery are still important health risks, with estimates of the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) in 1990 ranging from 110 to over 200 per 100,000 live births. Other major health problems for women include a very high prevalence of anaemia, at two thirds of all pregnant women, and widespread reproductive tract infections (RTIs). According to the 1993 World Development Report (WDR) "Investing in Health", the vast bulk of all these conditions can be successfully prevented or treated in a highly cost-effective manner within a primary health care (PHC) system, backed by appropriate first-level referral facilities and selected additional disease control interventions. 1.7 Primary Health Services. A life expectancy of 67 years could not have been achieved in a country as poor and as war-affected as Viet Nam without extremely effective basic health services. Viet Nam was in fact one of the pioneers of primary health care (see Annex I for a detailed description of the system), and has achieved a vast, dense and staff- intensive network of health facilities far exceeding those of its much richer neighbors. The
 - 3 - ratio of the lowest-level health facility (the commune health centre, or CHC) per million population is around 170 in Viet Nam, compared with 32 in Indonesia, 63 in China and 141 in Thailand; each CHC is staffed with about four health workers including an assistant doctor, a secondary midwife, a nurse and a pharmacist. Average traveling time to obtain a modern contraceptive method (mostly supplied through public facilities) is reported to be only 20 minutes. Only three percent of rural households live in communes without a CHC, and a Government-financed program of CHC construction plans to fill these gaps within the next few years. Similarly, Viet Nam's hospital bed ratio of one per 389 persons compares favorably with one per 465 in China, 665 in Thailand and 1,743 in Indonesia. 1.8 Viet Nam is also performing relatively well in terms of many basic primary health care programs, given the lack of adequate financing which continues to be a major constraint to full coverage and effectiveness. According to the 1994 Intercensal Demographic Survey (ICDS), seventy five percent of children have received at least one immunization. Over 40 percent of pregnant women are receiving full tetanus toxoid vaccination. The Control of Diarrheal Diseases (CDD) program, which focuses on use of oral rehydration therapy, is being expanded, it now covers over 80 percent of all communes and more than half of CHC staff are fully trained. Most mothers are reported to maintain or increase normal levels of fluids for children with diarrhea and to continue breastfeeding them, although use of packaged oral rehydration salts or home solutions itself is still low. The ARI control program is now estimated to cover 40 percent of all children across all provinces, though less than a quarter of children yet receive the correct antibiotic treatment. According to the 1994 ICDS, 55 percent of mothers receive some ante-natal care from a medical or paramedical professional, and nearly 60 percent deliver in health facilities. Forty four percent of married women are using a modern family planning method. 1.9 Most of this primary health care was and is delivered at the CHCs and District Health Centres (DHCs), which in many ways form a partnership through which DHCs supplement and support CHCs through supervision, referral and mobile teams which tour CHCs to deliver services beyond the capability of CHC staff For example, the 1994 ICDS reported that 37 percent of all mothers delivered at CHCs, and another 9 percent at DHCs, together making up more than 80 percent of all institutional deliveries. Likewise, 45 percent of women using modern contraception obtained it at CHCs in 1988 and 44 percent in 1994, according respectively to the 1988 Viet Nam Demographic and Health Survey and the 1994 ICDS. I.10 However, the disappearance in recent years of the agricultural cooperative system which largely financed and supported CHC staff (see para. 1.13), combined with pressures on public expenditure since the late 1980s, has resulted in a marked deterioration of the public health service at all levels. This is manifest in dilapidated buildings, acute shortages of furniture, equipment and supplies, and low morale and productivity of health workers due to declining real salaries and poor working conditions. In some facilities, health
 - 4 - workers have not only been sleeping on the premises during their duty but staying there on a longer-term basis. While there are still no shortages of health staff on paper, except for secondary midwives, many health workers are now said to be working only a few hours per day in health facilities, in order to supplement their salaries through other income-earning activities. At the same time, the cost of using public health care has risen through the introduction in 1989 of official user fees for all facilities except CHCs, and private health practitioners and pharmacies have been licensed. 1.11 As a result of all these factors, utilization rates for public health facilities have fallen dramatically for clinical and in-patient services. Numbers of annual out-patient consultations halved from 2.1 per capita in 1987 to 0.9 in 1993, and numbers of annual inpatient admissions fell from 105 per 1,000 population to 68 in 1990. Many CHCs and DHCs are said to be catering to less than 10 outpatients seeking minor curative care per day, and performing only a few deliveries per month. According to recent data from the 1992-93 Viet Nam Living Standards Survey (VLSS), one third of the population currently go to any health practitioner when sick, with the other two-thirds resorting to self- medication. Among the poorest 20 percent of the population, 70 percent self-medicate. The degree of substitution between public and private providers over time is not known, but of those who do see a health practitioner, more than half currently see a private provider; poorer patients are more likely to see a paramedic and richer patients a doctor. Among public facilities, the poorest are more likely to visit CHCs and richer groups a hospital. Thus the poor gravitate towards the lowest levels of service in both private and public sectors for curative care, no doubt because they entail the least immediate direct expense. 1.12 The overall picture is thus of a public health care sector which has reached a crossroads. Basic primary health care interventions of a preventive or palliative nature are being delivered, but coverage is still well below satisfactory levels and the quality of services is uncertain. If facilities and staffing continue to deteriorate, and resources are not forthcoming for upgrading and maintaining a well-supplied and well-functioning system, it is likely that even these basic PHC services will cease to perform adequately. Because of resource constraints and the ready availability of pharmacies, the public system is already little used by any section of the population for basic curative care. 1.13 Financing of Health Services. Data on health expenditure for Viet Nam are weak and need further review and analysis. However, on the basis of available information, it appears that state financing for the public health care system is split between central and local government budgets. The centre picks up the costs for central and branch hospitals, preventive health care (including the national malaria, TB and ARI control programs, EPI and the national MCH program), medical training and medical research, amounting all together to about one quarter of the state budget for health. The other three-quarters of the budget is spent by local (provincial and district) governments, which finance the costs of their respective hospitals with district budgets also picking up
 some costs for CHCs. The salaries of CHC staff and maintenance of CHC facilities were in the past supported almost entirely outside the state health budget by the commune agricultural cooperatives, through contributions in cash, kind or labor. However the collapse of the cooperative system has reduced commune-level financing to derisory levels. A decision was therefore made in 1994 to phase in financing of CHC staff salaries by the regular state health budget over the next three years, with two-thirds of communes covered so far. 1.14 In 1993, overall state budget expenditures on health amounted to 1,442 billion dong (about US$144 million), or some 20,000 dong (US$2) per capita; this was about half the budget for education. About 90 percent of this amount was spent on curative care in hospitals and only about 2 percent on CHCs. According to the 1992-3 VLSS, another 7,500 billion (US$750 million) dong were spent directly on health care by households, or some 104,000 dongs (US$10) per capita Almost all of this private expenditure went for purchase of drugs. Thus total per capita annual health spending in Viet Nam would be around US$12, most of it used for medicines. 1.15 By comparison, the 1993 WDR estimates that a minimal package of essential clinical health services would cost about US$8 per capita in a low-income country, all calculated to be highly cost-effective and all to be delivered at district and lower levels of the health system. A further basic package of "public health" programs (including immunization and family planning), which benefit the entire community and are also highly cost-effective, would cost another US$4. The two packages together would make up US$12 per capita, or roughly what Viet Nam already spends. It would seem therefore, that total health expenditure in Viet Nam could be adequate for basic health needs, provided the allocation of spending were appropriate. Since health budgets and data on private expenditure in Viet Nam are insufficiently detailed to separate out spending by the -R basic needs categories, it is impossible to judge just how appropriate current patterns of expenditure actually are. However, it seems extremely likely that too little is being spent at the lower levels of public and private health systems and on basic cost- effective clinical and "public health" services. 1.16 Development of Family Planning Policies and Programs. Concern over population growth has a long history in Viet Nam. Rapid population growth in the Red River Delta, an area of recurring past food shortages, induced the government in northern Viet Nam to promulgate an official population policy as early as 1963. The goals of this policy were set as a reduction of the current population growth rate of 3.5 percent to 2 percent and achievement of an average family size of 2 to 3 children with 5-6 years spacing between births. To support the policy, use of condoms and the MJD was promoted and abortion services began to be made available at health facilities. No equivalent policies were established in southern Viet Nam, where the pronatalist attitudes of the French colonial regime and the Catholic church had long been dominant, but family planning services were available in urban areas. However the subsequent decade of war severely
 limited resources for family planning throughout the country, though USAID did begin funding for population and FP programs in the South in the early 1970s. 1.17 After reunification, Government took a succession of steps to standardize and increase the availability and uptake of family planning throughout Viet Nam, spurred on by alarm over the rapid growth of population revealed by the 1979 census. The Family Law of 1977 attempted to promote the protection of women's rights, and the Ministry of Health (MOH) worked to improve availability of FP and abortion services through public sector facilities with help from the Institute for the Protection of Mothers and Newborn (IPMN). A cadre of volunteer outreach workers, called "motivators", was also established at the hamlet level by various mass organizations, such as the Women's Union, the Peasants' Union and the Farmers' Union; their task was to promote the adoption of family planning among hamlet families. 1.18 In 1984, the National Committee for Population and Family Planning (NCPFP) was set up to implement the national population policy and to direct the national family planning program. A large part of NCPFP's staff was drawn from MOH, and a major principle of its mandate was that family planning services would continue to be delivered entirely through the health system. The NCPFP was to contract out the actual delivery of FP and abortion services to MOH, but would coordinate all population and family planning activities in the country and would itself implement a nationwide program to promote family planning through social mobilization efforts. To this end, a network of subsidiary committees was established at provincial (PCPFPs), district (DCPFPs) and commune (CPFPBs) level, all with participation of the corresponding level of People's Committees, mass organizations and health authorities. 1.19 In 1988, Viet Nam officially introduced a national "one-child or two-child" policy, formalizing a system of childbearing guidelines, free provision of contraceptives and abortion, and economic incentives and disincentives. Following the licensing of a private health sector, FP and abortion services also became openly available through the private sector, though public facilities are still by far the most important providers. In 1993, the NCPFP set up its own nationwide cadre of hamlet-level outreach workers called "collaborators", who receive a small allowance plus performance-based incentives for the promotion of family planning, including distribution of condoms and oral contraceptives. Annex 2 provides a detailed description of the entire current system of family planning activities. 1.20 Donor Activities. Several donors have been active in the population and family planning fields in Viet Nam. USAID provided some support in the south during the early 1970s, but this ceased in 1975 and has not been resumed to date. The major donor since reunification has been UNFPA, who are now nearing the end of their fourth year country assistance cycle and have been contributing about US$4-5 million per year to the FP program. They have provided assistance for a full range of population and family planning
 - 7 - activities, comprising demographic and FP data collection and research (including the 1989 census, the 1988 Viet Nam Demographic and Health Survey, and the 1994 Intercensal Demographic Survey), FP/MCH services, contraceptive supplies and equipment, IEC (including population education), training and MIS. The fifth country cycle is currently under preparation. Other donors in the field include UNICEF, GTZ, Australia and various NGOs, who have mainly supported small projects in selected provinces. 1.21 Family Planning Status. These family planning efforts were remarkably successful in their early stages. The 1988 Viet Nam Demographic and Health Survey (VNDHS) reported a national contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) of 53 percent of currently married women of reproductive age, with 95 percent of married women knowing of at least one modem family planning method. This total CPR was made up of a CPR for modem methods of 38 percent and a CPR for "non-modern", "traditional" or "natural" methods (mainly withdrawal and rhythm) of 15 percent. The total fertility rate (TFR) was estimated from the same survey and from the 1989 census at just under 4 births per woman for the previous year, down from over 6 in the late 1950s and around 5 in 1979. Moreover, norms of fertility control and small families appeared to be taking hold; according to the VNDHS, the average preferred number of children for young married women (those married less than 5 years) was 2.6 and only 35 percent of all women wanted any more children. 1.22 This success was achieved using a remarkably limited and inexpensive approach to FP service delivery. Of current acceptors in the 1988 VNDHS, 62 percent were using the IUD, amounting to one-third of all currently married women in Viet Nam. Another 29 percent of contraceptors were using "traditional" or "natural" methods, mainly consisting of withdrawal and rhythm. The third most important method was sterilization (mostly mini-laps, rarely post-partum) at 6 percent of contraceptors. Only two percent were using condoms and less than one percent the pill. Thus the vast majority of FP users were relying on methods that either entailed no cost at all or required only very infrequent, or once-off, minor surgical procedures with minimal supplies and re-usable equipment. Although traditional methods usually have high user failure rates, experience even in developed countries such as the USA shows that procedure-based methods are among the most cost-effective of contraceptive choices. 1.23 Moreover, most modern FP services, and hence most of the procedures, have been and are provided through lower-level public health facilities. In 1988, almost all family planning users had obtained modem methods from the public sector; 45 percent had received services at CHCs, 37 percent at district hospitals or intercommunal polyclinics, and 12 percent at provincial hospitals. Even by 1993 and 1994, only about 10-11 percent of all modem-method FP users had obtained a method privately according to the VLSS and ICDS, and the VLSS reported that they were largely users of pills and condoms. Given Viet Nam's generously-staffed and extremely dense network of public health
 - 8 - facilities, and their low current case-loads at the lower levels, the provision of minor outpatient procedures such as IUD insertions, mini-laps and vasectomies (nowadays mainly done with the minimal no-scalpel technique) would entail minimal incremental costs per family planning user. 1.24 Unfortunately this method mix, however cost-efficient, is far from optimal from the standpoint of reproductive and women's health. Heavy use of IUDs is problematic in the circumstances of 'Viet Nam for several reasons. The presence of the device may promote or exacerbate existing RTIs and the insertion procedure itself carries an additional risk of introducing infection unless done with the utmost skill and vigilance. These general risks become a cause for serious concem where the incidence of RTIs is already high, as in Viet Nam. All but the recently developed progestin-bearing IUDs often induce heavy menstrual bleeding, which is undesirable where high percentages of women are already anaemic, as in Viet Nam. In addition, the IUD does have a significant, though small, failure rate; and armong those pregnancies that occur with the device still in place, a high proportion will spontaneously abort at any stage of gestation. This additional burden on women's health is particularly undesirable where the abortion rate is already high, as in Viet Nam. 1.25 Heavy use of withdrawal and rhythm is also problematic. Though these methods appear to carry little or no health risks in themselves, their failure rate is high among all but the most committed and well-supervised users. This in turn is likely to result in high rates of abortion. The usefulness of sterilization is limited. It is an essential part of any FP program for older couples who decide that they have completed their families, but it is inevitably restricted to this category of user and cannot be used for the spacing of births so important to matemal and child health. The major gap in the program method mix at present is thus the lack of effective, non-invasive, easily reversible methods that can be used for birth spacing purposes and by younger couples who have not completed their families. Pills and injectables are the most important methods in this category, followed by the condom, which also protects against RTIs, and Norplant. 1.26 Over the years, Viet Nam had thus developed a cost-efficient and initially effective family planning prograrn, which however suffered from some important deficiencies. Perhaps because of these, the program's progress appears to have slowed in recent years. The 1993 Multiround Survey (MIS) reported only an insignificant further rise in the total CPR to 54 percent, with a small rise in the modem methods CPR to 41 percent and a small decline in the non-modern methods CPR to 13 percent. Corresponding values for the much smaller-sample 1992-93 VLSS were a somewhat higher total CPR of 57 percent, which however included much multiple use of traditional methods with modern methods. The 1994 Intercensal Demographic Survey (ICDS) reported a sharp rise in the total CPR to 65 percent, but the C]PR for modern methods increased only marginally to 44 percent, while the CPR for non-rnodern methods jumped to 21 percent. Thus overall, the use of modern methods of contraception appears to have risen by only six points between 1988
 -9- and 1994, from 38 percent to 44 percent, with an equivalent increase occurring in the use of non-modern methods from 15 percent to 21 percent. 1.27 The pattern oif FP method mix did not evolve significantly in any desirable direction during the six years between 1998 and 1994. The 1992-93 VLSS showed much the same method mix as in 1988, except for slightly increased pill and condom use and some multiple use of traditional methods in combination with them. The 1993 MRS also reported a broadly similar mix, though the range of methods had widened. Use of the IUD had risen a little to 65 percent of contraceptors; the share of sterilization had remained constant at 6 percent; use of pills and condoms had risen to around 3 percent each; another fraction of a percent were using injectables, Norplant or diaphragms; and the share of traditional methods had fallen a little to 21 percent. 1.28 The 1994 ICDS did report some changes, but these cannot be viewed as positive overall. Similar percentages of contraceptors as in 1993 were using sterilization (6 percent) and the pill i(3 percent) and injectables and diaphragms/jelly (a fraction of a percent in total); condoms had doubled their share to 6 percent; the percent using IUD had dropped to 51 percent, but this was due largely to the much increased percentage relying on rhythm and withdrawal (32 percent combined). The proportion of married women using the IUD barely changed across all surveys from 1988 to 1994, remaining always between 33 and 35 percent. Thus family planning in Vietnam remains heavily focused on quick and simple minor surgical procedures with important health drawbacks, and a substantial and growing fraction of users continue to resort to no-cost but ineffective traditional practices. 1.29 During these same six years from 1988 to 1994, fertility fell more than might have been expected from the above trends in contraceptive use and mix, but still less than would have been desirable. The TFR reported for the previous year declined from just under 4 in the 1988 VNDHS to 3.5. according to the 1993 MRS and to 3.3 according to the 1992-3 VLSS. The 1994 ICDS reported an average TFR for the years 1989-1993 of 3.3 and a value of 3.1 for 1993 itself It is suspected that at least part of this decline was due to the use of pregnancy termination services, since overall the method mix has changed to favor the less effective non-modern methods whose failures appear to provide an important fraction of termination requests (see para. 1.32). However even a TFR of 3.1 is still much above replacement level, which at Viet Nam's very low level of mortality would be a TFR of under 2.2 births per woman. 1.30 Pregnancy termination plays a considerable role in the regulation of fertility in Viet Nam. The term "pregnancy termination" comprises two separately defined procedures in the country. More than half of all termination procedures performed in the country today are recorded as "menstrual regulation" (MR); these safer and less traumatic procedures are performed within a couple of weeks of a missed period, often without a pregnancy test, and require only a special syringe and no dilatation of the cervix. Only later procedures,
 - 10 - using standard abortion techniques, are recorded as "abortions" in Viet Nam. Both types of procedure are legal and available from public health facilities, as well as from the private sector. Neither type is considered as a family planning method, but only as a back- up in case of contraceptive failure. 1.31 Taking both types of pregnancy termination together and classifying both as abortions, over a million abortions are now performed annually in Viet Nam according to service statistics. This amounts to about two abortions for every five births. The corresponding total abortion rate (TAR), an analogous measure to the TFR, has been estimated from these figures at 2.5 abortions per woman over her reproductive lifetime. This would be the third highest level of abortion recorded in the world, surpassed only by Romania and the former Soviet Union where contraceptives have been notoriously difficult to obtain. Such a high level is unexpected in a country which (unlike Romania and the former Soviet Union) has been actively promoting and providing family planning for many years, and has achieved a total CPR of 65 percent. 1.32 Further data on abortion come from the 1988 VDHS and the 1994 ICDS, in which women were asked if they had ever had an MR or abortion. However these data must be treated with caution, since severe underreporting is almost always expected in direct questioning of women on their abortion experience, and seems to have occurred even in the relatively unthreatening circumstances of Viet Nam. In 1988, 7 percent of ever married women reported having had a termination, with a roughly fifty-fifty split between the two procedures. In 1994, this percentage had risen to 13 percent, with these women reporting an average of 1.25 procedures. Nearly 60 percent claimed to have been using contraception at the time of conception; of those women reporting a recent termination (since 1991) following a method failure, nearly 60 percent had been using withdrawal or rhythm. Given that only 20-30 percent of contracepting women were users of these two methods, it appears that the failure rate of these methods is an important contributor to the need for pregnancy termination. 1.33 According to the 1988 VDHS, 74 percent of all terminations in public facilities took place at district hospitals or polyclinics, another 18 percent at provincial hospitals, and four percent each at CHCs and central hospitals. Generally speaking, MRs tend to be performed at the lower levels of the health system while women would be progressively referred up for terminations at later stages. In many ways, therefore, the patterns of use of termination procedures match those for the standard FP outpatient procedures of IUD insertion and sterilization. 1.34 The overall picture therefore is of a family planning program whose performance is faltering because it is no longer adapted to its clients' needs. The small family norm is becoming ever more entrenched in Viet Nam, the proportion of all women wanting any more children declined from 35 percent in 1988 to 28 percent in 1994, while the average family size preferred by young married women fell from 2.6 in 1988 to 2.3 -- or close to
 - 11 - replacement -- in 1994. The total CPR has risen to the very high level of 65 percent of married women, indicating that couples are translating these desires for small families into action. Yet the use of modern methods has stagnated in recent years, while use of traditional methods is growing fast. Despite the heavy promotion of the IUD in the public program and the general lack of alternatives in the public sector, it has proved impossible to raise the level of use above a plateau of one third of married women. Similar though less intense promotion of sterilization has failed to raise the level of use above a plateau of 6 percent of couples. Where couples have had access through the private sector to the pill -- and even the not-then-licensed injectables -- use of these methods rises. Levels of pregnancy termination are extremely high. It is hard to avoid the conclusion that couples are resorting to traditional methods and (partly as a result of their use) to termination because they lack a suitable choice of temporary and reversible modern methods. While such a combination may reduce fertility, it cannot be considered a desirable or sustainable approach to family planning from the viewpoint of family health and welfare. 1.35 Financing of Family Planning. Funding for population and family planning activities in Viet Nam is made up of a mix of domestic and donor funding. In the past, the share of donor financing was as much as 30 to 40 percent, but this has now fallen to around 20 percent. Much of the contribution of donors has been in kind, such as contraceptive commodities, equipment and technical assistance; UNFPA alone has provided US$2-3 million worth of contraceptives per year in recent years. Total donor support for 1994 is estimated at about US$5.6 million. 1.36 Domestic population/FP funding largely flows through the national budget of the NCPFP, which in 1994 reached about 228 billion dongs or US$20.7 million. Local governments at provincial and district level, and commune authorities, are also expected to contribute funds to their respective PCPFPs, DCPFPs and CPFPBs; in 1994, provincial budget funding for population/FP amounted to 23 billion dongs, or around one-tenth of central funding, though funding at lower levels is difficult to track. Altogether, total government spending on population and family planning may have amounted to somewhat over 251 billion dongs or nearly US$23 million. Thus annual domestic public expenditure per capita for the five to six million current family planning users would come to about US$3.50 - 4.50. Donor support would add in another US$1 or so, making total public spending about US$4.50 - 5.50. According to the VLSS, private spending might amount to an additional total US$3 million, or another US 50 cents per user, yielding a grand total of public plus private annual spending on family planning of US$5-6 per FP user. These are extremely low levels of spending compared with a typical annual FP program cost of US$10-20 per user in the developing world, and no doubt reflect the extremely cost- efficient FP method mix developed in Viet Nam. 1.37 A substantial fraction of domestic population/FP funding is transferred through the NCPFP and its subsidiary committee network to the health system, to finance the delivery of FP services. In 1994, a formal system of "responsibility contracts" was established,
 - 12 - whereby the PCPFPs, DCPFPs and CPFPBs enter into annual contracts with health service authorities at the corresponding level. Funds flow down from NCPFP to each subsidiary CPFP level and are then released out to health authorities. The contracts specify targets to be achieved by the service providers and the budget that will be provided to reach the given targets. Targets are specified in terms of basic numbers, such as numbers of acceptors for a given method or of different types of procedures to be performed annually. Corresponding budgets are calculated on the basis of a standard unit cost per procedure etc., and appear to cover only the incremental costs to the health system of providing these FP services. Achievement of targets is monitored regularly, often monthly, and it appears that the quarterly release of funds to health authorities for each quarter is adjusted according to their actual previous performance. 1.38 Other items funded through the NCPFP and the subsidiary CPFP network include incentives for adoption of a method (paid to both acceptors and the collaborators who motivate them), allowances for collaborators, training and management costs of the CPFP system, equipment and contraceptive commodities, in-service FP training of health workers, and the costs of conventional IEC activities. Only about 7 percent of these funds are spent at the central level, with the rest being disbursed through the lower levels of the system. In addition, just under one quarter of the NCPFP budget goes to administrative costs of the entire CPFP system plus infrastructure costs. B. CURRENT ISSUES AND NEEDS IN THE SECTOR Family Health 1.39 The health sector in Viet Nam today faces many challenges. These are laid out in the Staff Appraisal Report for the National Health Support Project (Report No. 14971- VN), which is designed to support Government in meeting and overcoming them. For family health, however, the major and overriding issue is the need to revitalize the state primary health care system, defined according to WDR principles as the commune and district-level network of facilities. It is at these levels that many of the most cost-effective public health and clinical services are delivered, such as short-course chemotherapy for tuberculosis, treatment of diarrhea, malaria, and respiratory infections, and immunisations. These basic functions, which are almost all of a preventive or palliative nature, are not in general provided in a technically satisfactory and cost-effective manner by the private sector. According to what survey data exist, Viet Nam's developing private sector, which is still largely centred on curative care, self-medication and pharmacies, is not so far playing an important role in this type of basic health care. The private sector does appear to be substituting for public provision of some curative care, but even this is largely in the form of self-medication with purchased drugs, and therefore of unknown and dubious quality. Thus, though the private sector will have an increasingly important role to play in Viet Nam's health sector, there will in the foreseeable future be no practical alternative to the public PHC system for the maintenance and further improvement of basic and cost-
 - 13 - effective primary health programs such as maternal care, family planning and immunization, as well as a safety net of minor curative care for the very poor. There is therefore an urgent need to restore operating conditions and staff morale at these grass- roots facilities to normal working order, through upgrading of physical premises, supplies, staff salaries and staff skills. 1.40 Adequate primary health services are not needed only to maintain Viet Nam's current low levels of mortality and to improve health among all sections of the community in a cost-effective manner. They are also essential to the effective delivery of family planning. As described above, over 80 percent of users of modern methods had obtained services at either commune or district level in 1988, and this pattern does not appear to have changed significantly by 1994. In addition, experience worldwide has demonstrated that in the long run, family planning is most acceptable and most effectively practiced when FP services are well embedded in a health care system which delivers trustworthy maternal and child health (MCH) care. Such integration of family planning into family health care, which was recently strongly and unanimously endorsed at the Cairo International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD) in 1994, has been a principle of Viet Nam's family planning program from the beginning. It urgently needs reinforcement now that the country's formerly successful PHC system has come under pressure. 1.41 Within the family health care sector, there are also some key issues and needs regarding particular health conditions and service delivery constraints. Some aspects of maternal and infant health care require special attention and improvement, notably specific antenatal interventions such as anaemia prophylaxis and treatment and tetanus toxoid (TT) vaccination and better facilities for first-level referral of complicated deliveries. CDD and ARI programs for children have still a long way to go in terms of both coverage and effectiveness. Child nutrition interventions through health services, including growth monitoring and the promotion of optimum birth spacing and breastfeeding practices, are relatively underdeveloped at the primary level. Regarding other aspects of reproductive health, the high incidence of both RTIs and abortion is acknowledged to be a serious issue for women's health, though far too little is known about the underlying causes of either. 1.42 Outstanding service delivery issues relate mainly to quality, outreach and areas where normal patterns of service delivery are inadequate. Quality problems are due mainly to the severe decline in financial support for the PHC system, which has resulted in low staff attendance and morale, and in lack of adequate regular refresher training to keep skills up to date and maintain interest; the consequent declines in facility utilization have set up a vicious circle whereby skills are further eroded through lack of practice and staff morale and involvement in their work sink even lower. Improved inputs and resources are needed to break this cycle. Another aspect of quality concerns the current organization of primary health service delivery, which is excessively fragmented and verticalized by
 - 14 - specific intervention, so that mothers must visit several different facilities or providers to obtain a complete package of maternal or child care, or even a full range of contraceptive services. The design of primary health care delivery needs to be adjusted to make the convenience and needs of the client the central principle. 1.43 Health outreach problems also originate from changes in commune organization and health financing patterns. The old system of village health workers, usually primary nurses, broke down with the collapse of the cooperative system, but has not been replaced by any equivalent network because of the pressures on public health expenditure. The lack of health outreach is all the more felt since the CHC system itself has been deteriorating at the same time. 1.44 There is also a serious and well-established national deficit of one important grassroots health worker, namely the secondary midwife who is a key member of the CHC establishment. Over sixty percent of CHCs are now estimated to be without a secondary midwife (see Annex 1). The prospects for remedying this deficit in the short and medium term are dim, and therefore strategies for supplying the lack need to be identified and tried out. 1.45 All these deficiencies in service delivery have particularly severe consequences in those areas of Viet Nam where coverage and access to services is inherently difficult because of remoteness or scattered and sparse patterns of population settlement; these are mostly mountainous regions where Viet Nam's disadvantaged ethnic minority groups are concentrated (see paras. 4.18-4.26). New and innovative approaches to service delivery need to be tried in such areas. Population and Family Planning 1.46 Viet Nam's family planning program must, for the foreseeable future, continue to be mainly state-financed and managed, given the embryonic state of development of the private FP sector and the highly cost-effective broad societal benefits to be derived from effective fertility regulation across all groups in society. It has enjoyed a very successful and cost-efficient first phase, using an approach which was based on low-cost minor surgical procedures delivered at low-level health facilities, and backed by an extensive campaign of social mobilization to promote small families and to recruit and maintain uptake of family planning services. However this approach was never optimal from the health standpoint and seems now to be reaching its natural limits, with growth in prevalence of modern contraceptive methods stagnating in recent years. Yet fertility is still much above the replacement level required to balance Viet Nam's very favorable mortality and to reduce population growth to the minimum needed for successful national development. There is also a particular need to increase the availability of modern and effective temporary methods among younger women and for birth spacing purposes, aspects of family planning which are very important for reproductive and child health but
 - 15 - which have to date been underemphasized in the Viet Nam program. The high incidence of pregnancy termination, moreover, is a very strong indicator of unsatisfied demand and need for appropriate and effective contraception, and in itself is potentially very damaging to women's health. For all these reasons, the major overriding issue in population and family planning is the urgent need to develop a new and broader approach to family planning which will be suitable for a maturing program like Viet Nam's, which will stimulate faster progress in contraceptive use and fertility reduction, and which will better promote reproductive health. Though not as cost-efficient as the current procedure-based program, this approach represents the only way of achieving the country's broad demographic and health objectives. Costs can still be held down by the continued use of Viet Nam's PHC system at the lower levels to deliver the bulk of these broader-based services. 1.47 Government is keenly aware of these problems and issues, and has formulated a set of policies and strategies aimed at developing a broader approach to family planning in Viet Nam. These are set out in the Aide-Memoire presented to the Cairo ICPD conference in September 1994 by the Government of Viet Nam. The major principles of the family planning program are: (a) a reaffirmation of Government's position that population and family planning are an important part of the national development strategy and a prominent factor in socio-economic development, playing a fundamental role in raising the quality of life for all; hence approval of the integration of population and development, with population placed in the context of poverty alleviation, building of an equitable, civilized and happy society, and ensuring of sustained and sustainable economic growth and development; (b) adherence to the principle of voluntary participation in family planning, based on full information, combined with responsibility of each couple and individual for the numbers, spacing and timing of their children; (c) recognition of the right of every person to reproductive health care; (d) advocacy of the integration of family planning with maternal and child health care in order to reduce maternal and childhood mortality; (e) recognition of the role of abortion as not a method of family planning in itself, but rather a response to women's right to choice and to safe abortion; and (f) recognition of the need to reduce the incidence of abortion to a minimum through a strengthened family planning program.
 - 16 - 1.48 Strategies to implement these policy principles overlap considerably. They share a common approach to family planning as a broad-based program which seeks to satisfy client demand and ensure health benefits through provision of a wide range of contraceptive methods, good-quality clinical services, extensive IEC and counseling, and constant concern for family health. The strategies that focus on family planning itself include: (a) efforts to diversify and increase the choice of contraceptive methods available to couples, so that they have more options among modern and effective short-term, reversible and spacing methods; this would include intensive promotion of oral contraceptives (both the combined formula for general use and the progestin-only formula for breastfeeding mothers), condoms, injectables, Norplant, and the latest designs of IUDs, (b) expansion of IEC programs and materials to inform couples through a variety of media about the advantages of small families and optimum birth spacing and timing, and about the contraceptive choices open to them, besides correcting mistaken beliefs and fears about particular methods; (c) refresher training for health providers, in order to bring their knowledge of all contraceptive methods fully up to date and to correct mistaken beliefs about particular methods; (d) better training in counseling for health providers to ensure that they promote appropriate use of all available methods and give correct information on the advantages and disadvantages of each method; (e) improved remuneration, training and working conditions for collaborators and motivators, coupled with a gradual phasing-out of incentives; (f) improved systems of supervision and monitoring to ensure that providers, motivators and collaborators are performing well and observing the major policy principles set out above; and (g) improved access to family planning services for groups that are currently underserved, such as the populations of many remote and isolated areas. 1.49 These strategies will also work in general to improve reproductive care and the integration of family planning with maternal and child care, as well as to reduce abortion. Additional priority areas for the improvement of reproductive health care overlap with the PHC needs outlined in paras. 1.39-1.45 above; they include: (a) safe delivery facilities for normal deliveries at commune level or, in isolated areas, the best possible care within the community;
 - 17 - (b) safe care and emergency transport for complicated deliveries at district level; (c) care of anaemia in pregnancy; (d) high-quality services for IUD insertion and pregnancy terminations, to prevent post-procedure infections; and (e) adequate treatment of common RTIs at the commune and district level. 1.50 Special additional strategies to improve the integration of family planning with maternal and child health care again overlap with PHC needs as outlined in paras. 1.39- 1.45; they include: (a) adjustment of health service organization at commune and district level to ensure that integrated MCH/FP packages of care are available to clients; (b) widening of the role of collaborators to include promotion of maternal and child health in addition to family planning; and (c) refresher training for health providers that will emphasize integration of MCH and family planning. 1.51 Special additional strategies to reduce abortion include: (a) action to ensure that every woman discontinuing an FP method (except to conceive) is provided with another method before leaving the facility or provider; and (b) action to improve post-abortion and post-partum counseling and services so as to ensure that an FP method is provided immediately after abortion and as soon as required after a birth. 1.52 Many of these policy principles and strategies build on existing policies, guidelines and best practices in Viet Nam. The challenge will be to improve and revitalize current average performance within a context of limited financial resources and an ailing primary health care system. C. BANK EXPERIENCE Lessons from Previous IDA Experience 1.53 IDA has experience with only one social sector project in Viet Nam to date, namely the Primary Education Project (effective January, 1994). The key lesson that has
 - 18 - emerged during the early stages of this project's implementation is the need to ensure that staff of the implementing agency are fully trained in IDA procedures before project start- up, particularly in procurement, and that they receive additional follow-up assistance during the initial implementation period. RMV implementation specialists are expected to play a key role in this process. Because of the general inexperience of NCPFP with self- implemented donor projects, it will be even more important than usual to ensure that initial project activities are carefully planned well in advance. Retrospective financing from the project will be available to provide any needed extra technical assistance. 1.54 However the NCPFP has benefited in these respects from the use of a PHRD Grant for the preparation of the project; this was executed by IDA but with RMV handling all local expenditures. The NCPFP Project Unit used PHRD funds to: conduct an extensive facilities survey, covering both infrastructure and utilization, in five project provinces; hold project planning meetings at provincial, district and commune level; conduct a management review of the NCPFP, including a brainstorming workshop for NCPFP department directors on strategic planning issues; procure local consultants for preparation of specific components; procure a vehicle, computers and other office equipment for the PU; and finance some of the PU's operating costs. In the process, PU staff acquired invaluable familiarity with IDA procurement, contracting and reporting procedures. Initially progress was slow, but with due assistance from RMV and international consultants, the PU staff quickly became effective partners in execution. Country Assistance Strategy 1.55 IDA's goals in Viet Nam, as laid out in the November, 1995 Country Assistance Strategy (CAS), are to promote broad-based economic development and to combat poverty. IDA's strategy in Vietnam largely reflects Government's own broad strategy for development (see para. 1 .5). It is made up of five elements: strengthening of macroeconomic management; support to the transition to a market economy; a leading donor role in infrastructure development; assistance to development and implementation of a poverty-alleviation strategy; assistance to development and implementation of a strategy for sustainable use of natural resources. This IDA strategy is to be pursued through a combination of adjustment lending, investment projects, economic and sector work, and technical assistance. 1.56 A key element in the strategy for poverty alleviation is to assist in the provision of basic social services to poor households, in the belief that sustainable social service delivery systems should be developed as the basis for human capital accumulation and national social protection. The Population and Family Health project is seen in the CAS as contributing to the poverty-alleviation strategy through: a) its development of sustainable family health and family planning systems; b) its targeting of specific components to particularly vulnerable groups; and c) its assistance towards resolving the urgent problem of rapid population growth. In addition, it complements the Primary Education Project,
 - 19 - another key contribution to the poverty alleviation strategy; on the one hand educated girls are more likely to reduce their fertility but require good-quality FP services in order to do so, and on the other hand reductions in fertility and population growth will enable future investment in education to focus more rewardingly on quality improvements rather than just expanding coverage to meet the needs of ever-increasing cohorts of children. The National Health Support Project is seen as a third key contributor to the poverty- alleviation strategy. Both the Population and Family Health project and the National Health Support Project also respond directly to the findings of IDA's "Poverty Assessment and Strategy Report"; in particular to the finding that insufficient resources are going to finance highly cost-effective public health and clinical services. 1.57 In addition to its impact on poverty alleviation, the Population and Family Health project will also contribute to the strategy for sustainable use of natural resources. The rapid growth of population in Viet Nam has put severe pressure on agricultural and forest land. Conservation and long-term sustainable use of these resources will not be possible without the reduction of population growth to a minimum, which in turn will require the reduction of fertility to replacement level. Rationale for IDA Involvement 1.58 IDA has for some years been engaged in a dialogue with Government on major issues in the population, health and nutrition sectors. This dialogue began in 1992 with the preparation of the "Viet Nam Population, Health and Nutrition Sector Review" and was sustained through the work carried out for the "Viet Nam Poverty Assessment and Strategy Report" (1995) and the preparation of the National Health Support Project and a nutrition project. Building on the advantage of this comprehensive sectoral context, the proposed project would provide an opportunity to focus on the specific needs of the population/family planning sector. 1.59 The project would support the new approach to population and family planning programs in Viet Nam which is outlined in Government's position paper presented at the Cairo conference. This approach, which seeks to strengthen the integration of family planning into the MCH and reproductive health context and to broaden the FP method mix substantially, requires investment on a massive scale and with in-depth technical inputs across the sector. The established donors in the field, notably UNFPA, UNICEF and GTZ, have made invaluable contributions to the FP program to date. However, IDA is in the unique position of being able to supply or mobilize both financial and technical resources on the requisite scale and with the requisite scope.

PROJECT IMPACT ON SOCIAL ISSUES Impact on Ethnic Minorities 4.18 According to the 1989 census, the population of Viet Nam was made up of 87 percent Kinh (ethnic Vietnamese) and of 13 percent ethnic minorities, who belonged to more than 50 different ethnic groups with distinct cultures. These ethnic minorities vary enormously in size; the two largest groups, Tay and Thai, have populations of over one million each, while some of the smallest are numbered only in the hundreds. They are found in all regions and provinces of Viet Nam, ranging from less than one percent to 96 percent of provincial populations in 1989 (see Annex 15). Subdivision of some provinces since 1989 complicates estimation, but roughly speaking, minority groups make up 50-80 percent of the population in three out of the 15 project provinces, and 15-30 percent in another six. A few of the minority groups, such as the Han Chinese, are either fully integrated into mainstream Kinh society or enjoy an equal or superior standard of living. However most are relatively disadvantaged. They mainly inhabit the mountainous, forested and remote parts of the country, often living in small and scattered settlements to which access is extremely difficult.
 - 50 - 4.19 Government has implemented several policies and programs aimed at improving the standard of living and meeting the special needs of these disadvantaged groups. In the family planning area, the national "one or two-child" policy has been modified to suit their minority status by allowing three children to couples belonging to mountain-dwelling minority groups. In health, special programs have been set up to try to improve the supply of health staff for minority communities, including special scholarships for minority girls and boys wishing to become doctors, nurses or midwives. However it is acknowledged that health and FP services still remain extremely deficient in many minority areas. Consistent with the objectives of Operational Directive (OD) 4.20 on the protection of the interests of indigenous peoples and ethnic minorities, the project will therefore include special strategies to ensure equity in health and FP status between minority groups and their Kinh neighbors (see Annex 15). 4.20 As a preparatory step, two preliminary studies of ethnic minorities were undertaken during project preparation. The first was a desk study which collated available statistics and general information on ethnic minorities in Viet Nam. The second was a participative field study carried out by an anthropologist with long experience in the field in Thailand and Viet Nam, including one of the project provinces. It collected original data in a second project province through quick field surveys of health and FP status and access to services, and also held participative discussions with minority communities on their needs and preferences in family planning and family health. In addition, this study compiled the scanty information available on these topics for the country as a whole. 4.21 Available demographic data indicate that all of Viet Nam's minority groups except the Han lag behind the Kinh in terms of the demographic transition to low levels of fertility and mortality. According to the 1989 census, all the nine most numerous groups excepting the Han had TFRs above 4.0, with most above 5.0. By contrast, the Kinh TFR was estimated at 3.6 and the Han TFR at only 2.9. Similarly, all nine groups had IMRs higher than the estimated Kinh level of 39, except for the Han at 31; the range was from 41 to as high as 106, with most minority IMRs well above 50. Available socio-economic data show higher levels of poverty and illiteracy lying behind these demographic disadvantages. According to the 1993 VLSS, average annual expenditure, a proxy for income, was much lower for all minority groups (except the Han) than for the Kinh; typically expenditure was more than a third lower and sometimes almost two thirds lower. According to the 1989 census, literacy levels among the population aged 5 years and over were lower among all ethnic minorities, even the Han, than among the Kinh, of whom 87 percent were literate. There was however a considerable variation among minority groups; some had literacy rates of 80 to 83 percent, while others had rates as low as 10-20 percent. 4.22 The findings of these two preliminary studies also indicate that among at least some ethnic minorities, demand for PHC and modern FP services is quite as high as among the Kinh. There may be a greater preference for temporary and short-term contraceptive methods over permanent or long-term methods, but few other cultural
 - 51 - features have been found which would require adapting of regular FP and PHC services to suit local cultural attitudes and practices. The major disadvantages of these groups appear to arise from lack of access to such services, because of the difficult and remote terrain in which they tend to live. 4.23 Special strategies are needed under the project in order to improve access and quality of services among ethnic minorities up to the standard of their Kinh neighbors. The first requirement is a better data base. Baseline surveys will therefore be carried out early in the project among the most numerous ethnic minority groups in Viet Nam. These would assess current health and FP status and access to services, relative to neighboring Kinh communities. On this basis, a full set of strategies would be designed to remedy any disadvantages found. Annex 14 gives an outline of the scope and methodology which will be followed for these surveys. 4.24 It is already clear that the major focus of such strategies overall will be the improvement of access to good-quality family health services, with emphasis on extension of outreach in remote mountainous areas. As already described in paras. 2.15 and 2.25, a new system of village-based health posts would be piloted in these areas under Component 5 and then expanded to cover all such areas in the 15 project provinces under Component 1, if successful. In addition, under the accompanying pilot of an upgraded collaborator system providing a range of family health services, the new Family Health Workers in remote mountainous areas would be furnished with bicycles; additional transport would be provided for DHC mobile teams serving remote mountainous and delta areas; and special programs of recruitment and training of paramedical staff belonging to ethnic minorities would be developed and implemented. Other possible approaches to improving access to services might include special efforts to train traditional midwives to supervise home deliveries safely, and special incentive programs for private or NGO health practitioners or pharmacies willing to settle in or tour remote areas. Baseline studies for the 15 provinces, the formulation of appropriate special strategies, and the piloting of selected approaches will all be funded under Component 5 (paras. 2.24-2.25); extension of the health post and collaborator pilots (if successful), plus DHC mobile team transport and special training programs, would be funded under Component I (para. 2.15). 4.25 At national level, all components focusing on family planning will support a widening of the method mix and a new emphasis on temporary and short-term methods. Hence preferences for such methods among minority groups should automatically be catered for under the project. However, a special national FP strategy for ethnic minorities will also be formulated. It will aim to improve access to FP services and adapt IEC materials and activities, including training in counseling, as needed (see Annex 15). 4.26 In order to monitor and evaluate the implementation and impact of these special strategies for disadvantaged minorities, special follow-up surveys will be carried out for the most numerous minority groups (see Annex 14). During negotiations, Government
 - 52 - provided assurances that the project will be carried out in accordance with a strategy satisfactory to IDA, which will: (a) be designed on the basis of studies and surveys undertaken by qualified and experienced experts under terms of reference and timing satisfactory to IDA; and (b) include provisions for the informed participation of and consultation with a variety of representative communities benefiting under the project, in particular communities with ethnic minorities, to ensure that the design and implementation of the project adequately addresses the needs and cultural preferences of such communities [para. 6.1 (o)]. Impact on Women 4.27 The proposed project is intended to support strengthening of primary health care and family planning programs in Viet Nam, with a focus on improving maternal, family and reproductive health services. As a result, women will benefit from better access to higher-quality services offering a wider range of contraceptive methods, improved care in pregnancy and delivery, and better treatment of reproductive tract infections. As a result, the need to resort to abortion should decline and the number of unwanted or mistimed births should be reduced. Women would therefore be able to care for their children and families more effectively, as well as to increase their income-generating activities and their participation in development. The impact of the project on women is thus expected to be very favorable. E. ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT 4.28 Impact on the Environment. The project will have no effect on the environment.
