Component 1 of the project will deliver a package of inputs to upgrade PHC service delivery in 15 provinces. The inputs are civil works, equipment and furniture, essential drugs and medical supplies and refresher training; outreach systems might also be strengthened but this is not certain and hence will not be taken into account here. The incremental recurrent cost burden to be sustained after project implementation will comprise the maintenance of the upgraded civil works and equipment (which would be shared between the health and population/FP budgets), and annual drug and medical supplies plus logistics costs. These costs will be met out of the
 - 53 - regular health budget and would amount to approximately US$2.7 million per annum by 2002, or well under one percent of the projected health budget for 2002 (see Annex 16 for details). Incremental costs on this scale should not by themselves be difficult to sustain. 4.31 The National Health Support Project will provide a similar upgrading package over the same period to another 15 provinces, raising total coverage to more than half the country's population. However this would still only raise incremental recurrent costs for the 30 provinces together to around US$5.4 million or less than 1.5 percent of the national health budget. Taking a broader perspective, if the provincial upgrading package should succeed in improving service quality and utilization, Government might consider a similar upgrading program in the country's remaining provinces. At most, however, the recurrent cost burden from a similar investment program in the rest of the country would about double that generated by the two projects, to consume altogether no more than 3 percent or so of the national health budget. It does not appear, therefore, that the upgrading of Viet Nam's PHC services could create any major problem of sustainability. 4.32 Family Planning Program. Under the project, the contraceptive prevalence rate for modern methods is projected to rise by about 10 percentage points. Numbers of users will rise proportionately even more, since the population of reproductive age is also increasing. At the same time, the contraceptive method mix is projected to broaden and become more commodity-intensive. Thus total national costs for contraceptive commodities plus logistics costs (excluding condoms) are projected to rise from a current level of around US$3 million to around US$7.5 million by 2002. The increase of about US$ 4.5 million per year may be viewed as the recurrent cost burden generated overall by the project's activities, even though only a minor proportion of these contraceptive costs would be financed directly by the project by 2002. This increase plus the population/FP budget's share of maintenance costs would be equivalent to about 8.5 percent of the projected population/FP budget for 2002, a significant but sustainable increment. 4.33 Taking a wider perspective, however, the annual total contraceptive bill of US$7.5 million is the amount that would need to be sustained after the closure of the project, equivalent to about 13 percent to the projected total budget for population and family planning in 2002 (see Annex 16 for details). This scale of resource allocation for contraceptive supplies is not excessive by the standards of family planning programs worldwide. It should therefore be sustainable by the Government of Viet Nam even if all these supplies were to be financed by Government itself and provided free of charge through public programs. In fact, a proportion of users already obtain their contraceptive supplies from the private sector and the importance of both the private sector and social marketing is likely to grow substantially during the life of the project. A program of charges for public program users is also planned to be introduced during the second half of the project. It is moreover very likely that donor support to contraceptive supplies would continue to be significant after the year 2000, outside the umbrella of the project itself
 - 54 - The sustainability of the expanded contraceptive costs should therefore present no major problems. Institutional Sustainability 4.34 The project has been designed to avoid any serious problems of institutional sustainability after project closure. No permanent salaried staff have been added to either provincial health services or the FP program, and no major changes are to be made in their organizational structure or their tasks. Though some new approaches are to be tested under the project, such as health posts and strengthened outreach systems, they will be evaluated thoroughly for viability and sustainability before being expanded. The project should result in increased health and FP workloads, due to the planned upgrading of facilities, services and IEC, but the network of facilities and staff is currently so dense that their capacity to accommodate such increases is expected to be ample. There will be a massive temporary increase also in the IEC program, but the incremental activities are designed primarily to support the restructuring and upgrading of the FP program under the project itself Therefore, the level of IEC activities and expenditure would revert to the pre-project norm after project closure. Other elements of the project, such as management training and MIS upgrading, would improve the efficiency of program management and administration. No major issues of institutional sustainability are therefore anticipated.
 - 55 - 5. BENEFITS AND RISKS A. BENEFITS 5.1 There will be a range of overlapping benefits from the project. First, at the national level, the proposed strengthening of Viet Nam's family planning program should result in improved information, education and communication about family planning, better quality of family planning services, and a wider choice of methods for couples including those best suited to temporary use and for the purposes of birth spacing. In turn, these improvements should lead to greater demand for family planning and to more effective and prolonged use of contraception; hence to a reduction in the incidence of abortion, improved birth spacing and timing practices, smaller family sizes, lower fertility and reduced population growth. An average seven million contracepting couples would annually be beneficiaries of this strengthened FP program. 5.2 The benefits that would flow individually to women, children and famnilies would be improvements in maternal, child and reproductive health and in family welfare. The additional benefits that would flow to the entire economy and society of Viet Nam, comprising more than 80 million people by 2002, would include the reduction of long- term pressure on agricultural and forest land, on other natural resources, and on state and family budgets for the social services required for the care and education of child dependents. 5.3 Second, for the 15 project provinces where primary health care services would also be strengthened under the project, there will be additional benefits related to these interventions. As a result of the improvements in working conditions resulting from upgraded premises and adequate supplies of equipment and drugs, combined with improved knowledge and skills resulting from refresher training, primary health providers in these provinces should be enabled and motivated to deliver good-quality primary health services to the rural population. These would focus on maternal, child and reproductive health care (including family planning) and also provide treatment for major infectious diseases and minor ailments combined with screening and referral for more serious conditions. 5.4 This should lead to a number of health benefits to communities in these provinces, including reductions in morbidity and mortality from the communicable diseases of childhood, diarrheal and respiratory diseases, malaria, TB, reproductive tract infections, and conditions related to complications of pregnancy and delivery for mothers and to birth for infants. The entire population of the 15 project provinces, amounting currently to over 20 million or 28% of the total population of Viet Nam, would benefit from access to improved PHC services. Beneficiaries of the core PHC interventions, covering maternal and young child care plus FP, would amount to an average 5.4 million annually, made up of around 740,000 women requiring maternal care, around 1.7 million children under three
 - 56 - years of age and around 3.0 million contraceptors. These benefits should be particularly important to the poorest sections of rural communities, since they are the least able to purchase adequate replacement services in the private market. In addition, if the package of inputs provided by the project in these provinces (and likewise by the National Health Support Project in 15 other provinces) is successful in revitalizing their PHC systems, this should provide a powerful stimulus and model for similar strengthening in the remaining half of the country. The project's studies and pilots of the private sector (plus complementary policy studies under the National Health Support Project) would also lead to a better knowledge base for action to regulate and improve private sector services. 5.5 Without the project (and the accompanying National Health Support Project) Government is highly unlikely to be able to mobilize sufficient domestic or external funding for major upgrading of the FP program (including social marketing) or of primary health care in the provinces. Without such investment, the FP program would probably stagnate at its current level of modern method coverage and with its current method-mix. Through lack of choice and information, couples would increasingly resort to ineffective traditional methods. As a result, fertility decline would be slower and abortion rates would remain undesirably high. 5.6 Without major investment, the PHC system is likely to deteriorate still further to a point where even the major preventive programs decline in coverage and effectiveness. Since no effective private sector alternatives have developed for these types of health interventions, there will be a risk of resurgence of communicable disease epidemics and a stagnation or rise in child and maternal death rates. Such trends have already been observed in other countries or population groups where PHC systems have deteriorated. At the same time, curative care would continue to be dominated by self-medication from pharmacies of unknown quality and effectiveness and to a lesser extent by largely unregulated private providers. In such conditions, clients are unlikely to obtain the most cost-effective medical care for their illnesses, and rates of morbidity and mortality could not be minimized. B. RISKS 5.7 Technically, the packages of family planning and PHC interventions to be delivered under the project present little risk. The technologies and techniques for providing effective and good-quality FP and PHC programs and services are well-understood and well-tested around the world. Viet Nam's experience in both sectors is long and generally successful, demonstrating unquestionable ability to implement efficiently and sustained commitment to the goals of better health and reduction of fertility and population growth. The risks of the project relate more to the rapidly-evolving social and economic context of Viet Nam and the ability of the mature FP and PHC programs to change, as well as to the country's inexperience with IDA projects and procedures.
 - 57 - 5.8 For the FP program, the major overall risk is that despite high-level NCPFP commitment and the fresh inputs and strategic directions supported by the project, the expected broadening of the method mix and shift towards a client-oriented approach may not be achieved as rapidly as projected. One constraint might be the recognized difficulty in changing attitudes and practices among entrenched program managers and health providers. It might also prove harder than expected to correct current client misconceptions and shift client preferences towards less familiar methods. These risks will be minimized within the project by: intensive IEC activities; extensive training in appropriate counseling for all providers and motivating staff, management training and inputs for the CPFP network to promote fresh attitudes and thinking; and the use of the results of studies and pilot interventions financed under the service delivery model initiatives to support strategic rethinking and adoption of innovative approaches. 5.9 For the provincial strengthening of primary health, the major risk is related to the project's basic assumption that the utilization rates of public health facilities have fallen primarily because of poor service quality arising from resource constraints. It is possible, however, that public confidence in the state PHC system may not be retrievable at this point even if services are dramatically upgraded. Thus utilization rates might not recover despite the project's investments. If the private health provider sector develops sufficiently fast and effectively to provide a viable alternative to either the state system or self- medication from pharmacies, a further dimension to this risk would be added. However experience elsewhere has shown that state PHC systems continue to be attractive, particularly to the very poor, if access and quality of services can be assured. The project would minimize this risk by providing the complete package of inputs needed to achieve the required levels of access and quality. 5.10 Finally, there is a general risk that project implementation may prove to be slow and unsatisfactory, particularly in the area of civil works, because of Viet Nam's inexperience with IDA and ADB project procedures, coupled with the limitations of NCPFP management capabilities. This risk would be minimized by the management training and support to be provided to NCPFP and the subsidiary CPFP network within the project, and by a special civil works monitoring unit in the NCPFP PMU. Extensive training in IDA and ADB procedures is also planned prior to project implementation. The positive experience of NCPFP's use of the project's PHRD fund (see para. 1.54), combined with Viet Nam's successful management of PHC and FP programs in the past, despite adverse conditions, suggests that this risk is not unduly high.

 - 61 - Annex I THE PRIMARY HEALTH CARE SYSTEM IN VIET NAM Health Services 1. Health services in Viet Nam are organized on a four-tiered system. At the apex is the Ministry of Health (MOH), and below are the provincial, district and commune level health services. Central Level 2. The MOH is the main national authority in the health sector and directly manages faculty schools, national production units of drugs and medical equipment, and all centrally-based hospitals (19% of all hospital beds and 7% of all health/medical workers). The MOH, at the central level, is responsible for setting policy and technical directions for the entire country. 3. The MOH is organized into 13 functional departments responsible for different activities such as training, family planning, maternal and child health, equipment and construction, and finance, planning and policy. The MOH is assisted in its activities by a number of central specialty institutes which function as tertiary care referral centers such as the Institute of Hygiene and Epidemiology, Institute for the Protection of Mothers and Newborn, the National Institute of Nutrition, and a number of other institutes responsible for research, training and patient care in the areas of pediatrics, tuberculosis, pharmacy and traditional medicine. In addition to the MOH, there are a number of ministries which provide parallel health services (e.g. Ministry of Defense). 4. Over the years, Viet Nam has also developed a number of self-contained vertical health programs, including malaria, TB and ARI control, and CDD, with structures running from the central to the district level. These structures, though useful in focusing attention and resources on important public health programs, are proving inefficient in terms of duplication of resource allocation. Given the complex structure and overlapping functions at the central level, there is a broad recognition of the need to streamline the overall management of health services, as well as coordinate and integrate the vertical programs for better cost efficiency. Provincial Level 5. The next level is the provincial health services which is responsible for the center for preventive medicine stations, the local production of medical supplies, and referral laboratory facilities. The provinces also run provincial hospitals and in some cases, specialized hospitals (30% of all hospital beds). The provincial general hospitals are intended to be referral centers and typically have all seven departments (internal medicine,
 - 62 - Annex I obstetrics and gynecology, surgery, pediatrics, infectious diseases, traditional medicine and emergency ward). Manpower at the provincial level is 35% of the nation's total. However, in practice, few of the patients cared for at these hospitals come from outer communities and the vast majority reside in the general vicinity of the hospitals. The hospitals therefore serve basic curative needs which could be effectively attended to at lower levels of the health care delivery system. 6. One other important component of the provincial health services are the secondary medical schools. These schools train middle level health workers for their provinces, such as assistant doctors, secondary midwives, nurses and secondary pharmacists. District Level 7. The third level is the district level which is in charge of all medical facilities that are intermediaries between the provincial and commune levels. The three components of the district health services are the District Health Office which has surveillance and program management responsibilities; the preventive medicine services dealing with EPI, CDD, malaria control, vitamin A deficiency etc.; and the District Hospital which provides first referral facilities to the commune level. The latter two components are now merged into the District Health Centers which deal with both preventive and curative health services. 8. The district hospitals (18% of all hospital beds and over 30% of all health/medical staff) have excess bed capacity because, in the past, financial allocations were made based mainly on the number of beds they had. As a result, bed occupancy rates average only 50%. 9. Also, though most district health resources (manpower, finances, drugs, equipment etc.) are concentrated in the district hospitals, the support these hospitals provide to the lower levels vary in both quality and quantity. There is therefore an urgent need to improve the quality of services and focus the range of services provided at this level in order to facilitate its functioning as a first referral facility. 10. There is also a hybrid facility which overlaps several communes known as the inter-commune polyclinic (ICP). The ICPs (5% of all hospital beds) were envisaged as centers to provide basic services at a higher level of sophistication (with some specialties such as ophthalmology and dentistry), take referrals from CHCs and give supervision and other technical services, including training, to CHCs. However, the ICPs do not appear to be fulfilling this role, and in practice function as either CHCs or DHCs depending on their capacity. The Government is currently initiating discussions on the future role of the ICPs.
 - 63 - Annex I Commune Level 11. At the commune level, the unit of service delivery is the commune health center (CHC). Viet Nam has developed a wide network of commune health centers at the grassroots level and CHCs account for 28% of all beds and 22% of health/medical staff in the country. 93% of all communes have a CHC and the remaining communes (known as 'White communes') are to be provided with CHCs over the next three years. However, observations indicate that much work needs to be done on the quality of available CHC infrastructure. Many of these facilities are run-down and lack the most basic equipment and drugs. Also, though in theory the CHCs are to be staffed by 3 to 5 health workers, in practice over 60% of them lack even a secondary midwife. 12. Each commune consists of a cluster of hamlets or villages, which is the basic social unit in the country. Unfortunately, an outreach system (the brigade or primary nurse system) which was in existence during the years of the war, has collapsed and there is therefore no household level primary health system in Viet Nam. Private Health Sector and its role in Primary Health Service Provision 13. It is important to note the rising presence of the private sector in the provision of health services in Viet Nam. The government has permitted private practice since 1988, and this has resulted in the emergence of numerous pharmacies, and to a lesser extent clinics, in both urban and semi-urban areas. A major issue facing private practice is regulation to (a) ensure that standards of practice are set and enforced and (b) distinguish between official and private practice among workers in the public sector. 14. About 30% of health workers were forced into retirement due to economic difficulties including demilitarization. Most of these retirees have returned to their villages, and if well organized could be used to provide community-based health care, especially in rural areas. It will however be necessary to establish specific role and responsibilities for them in their communities.

 - 65 - Annex 2 THE FAMILY PLANNING SYSTEM 1. The population and family planning program in Viet Nam has a dual organizational structure which runs in parallel but is interactive and coordinated at the different levels. The service delivery function is lodged in the MOH, Department of MCH/FP, and all clinical family planning services are provided through the health system (see Annex 1). 2. In 1984, as part of an effort to improve the Government's capacity to manage and implement the population programs, the Council of Ministers created the National Committee for Population and Family Planning (NCPFP). In 1989, the status of NCPFP was further elevated to that of the apex body in advising the Government on policy formulation and program development. It is also responsible for intersectoral coordination in the implementation of family planning programs of various ministries, agencies, levels of government and mass organizations. The Minister of Population and Family Planning acts as Chairman of the NCPFP. He is aided by three coordinating Vice- Chairmen who are appointed by the Ministry of Planning and Investment, Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Health. 3. The NCPFP network extends downwards and is replicated at the provincial, district and commune levels. In addition, the NCPFP also has a collaborator network at the hamlet level which is responsible for outreach work in the field of population and family planning. In recent years, the CPFP network has been involved in the distribution of non-clinical contraceptives (condoms, resupply of pills), and it is estimated that 27% of couples received contraceptives from sources outside the health force. Also, the collaborator network is the only formal outreach system at the grass- roots level, and though currently not equipped to provide community-based primary health care, the collaborators have the potential to be developed into primary health outreach workers.

 - 67 - Annex 3 CRITERIA FOR SELECTION OF PROVINCES FOR PHC UPGRADING The selection of provinces followed three major principles: 1. Provinces with unfavorable fertility, family planning and health indicators would be given priority in coverage. The three fertility and health indicators taken into consideration were the total fertility rate, infant mortality rate and contraceptive prevalence rate. 2. To provide more equitable distribution of funds, provinces with substantial previous or current donor commitments were excluded, though they would still participate in those components of the project that are meant to be nationwide (such as IEC and management development). In effect, the scoring led to the exclusion of all provinces covered by the UNFPA third cycle, the UNFPA fourth cycle, AusAID- assisted provinces, GTZ-assisted provinces, as well as those selected for coverage under the National Health Support Project. 3. Among the remaining provinces, efforts would be made to cover as much of the rural population as possible. In addition to the above principles, consideration was given to the geographical spread of the provinces, and their management capacity. Viet Nam has seven geographical regions which differ in terms of various factors such as terrain, ethnic composition and access to health and family planning services. By choosing project provinces from the different regions, it would be possible to design and implement a project which reflects the differing needs of the regions. This criterion therefore allows for replication of the project, if successful, since the 15 project provinces could serve as models in the specific regions. The provinces selected to be covered under the project were also judged to have above-average management capacity. This was considered to be particularly important given that the Population and Family Health Project is the first of its kind in terms of size and scope; the success of such a project therefore depends heavily on the management capacity at both the central as well as provincial levels.

Definition: this indicator measures the proportion of women estimated to have direct complications that are managed in facilities that can provide the basic services that are required for obstetric complications 32. Background: five major conditions are responsible for the majority of maternal deaths in developing countries world-wide: hemorrhage, sepsis, eclampsia and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, obstructed or prolonged labor, and complications from abortion. Special MCH/FP training programs for CHC Staff in remote and mountainous areas: 22. There iis a severe shortage of health staff working in the remote mountainous areas of the country. In these areas, a significant proportion of the population are from minority groups with low levels of basic education. These low levels preclude candidates from the minority groups from qualifying for entry to the Secondary Medical Schools for formal health training. CHCs in these areas, if staffed at all, may have a staff member seconded from the DHC, often not from the region at all and not conversant with the local language. To improve basic health services in these areas, there is the need both to develop a strategy for increasing the number of health workers drawn from the minority groups, as well as to upgrade the skills of those staff already in service. Details are given in Annex 15.

Implementation programs will need to be drawn up for each objective-target group- message combination that sharpens the features for greater impact. For example, in targeting women with one child, women who are breast feeding the child would be addressed differently compared to women who have stopped breast feeding. To the former, the message concerning pills would advocate the progestogen-only pill, while to the latter the low-dose combined pill would be promoted. Again, messages for women in minority groups would be different, as also for women who are in remote areas and therefore less likely to be literate. In some urban areas such as Ho Chi Minh city, there may be local campaigns to alert teenagers about the need for safe sex. 9. The next step would be to create and produce the materials. This requires answering questions about what the target groups know, think and feel about the topic (KAPB data is useful here for segmentation, plus informal observation or small qualitative studies to really understand why people are holding the beliefs or practising the behavior that KAPB is showing), what symbols, language, phrases and other culture-related elements can be used in communication to establish closer links with the target group, and what opportunities or limitations are imposed by the media that will be carrying the message. E. Implementation: Field Activities 10. IEC activities in the field -- at the grass roots level -- are vital. Large sections of the population are not reached by mass media. Even when they are, grass- roots activities generate some excitement and stimulate discussion of the topic which has already been seen or heard on TV or radio. The impersonal nature of mass media, therefore, is replaced by a local, topical event and word-of-mouth channels. I1. This component provides for field activities through collaborators' home visits, wall paintings in communes, traditional drama for remote areas and special events tied in with local radio and TV. For example, as part of a "campaign approach" a district may ask all collaborators to launch an awareness drive for pills during a 6-week period, follow this by having wall signs painted in communes over the following four weeks and climax the campaign by having the district mobile teams carry a rented TV and video cassette player to show films and spots on pills. 12. An important requirement for this approach is that there should be close coordination between national IEC planning and provincial / district field activities. This will require an annual IEC plan which describes the combination of messages, target

Social Marketing 24. Social marketing is based on the principle that concepts and techniques normally used for selling commercial products can also be applied to promote socially desirable goods and services. Typically, the target for socially marketed products are the poorer sections of society and, therefore, the price set for such products is based on subsidy rather than full cost or market value. 25. Although social marketing in Viet Nam has been introduced recently, it has demonstrated that the promotion of branded contraceptives in an aggressive commercial manner is capable of delivering impressive results. This component aims to accelerate social marketing activity in the following ways: encouraging the promotion of pills, particularly to lower income urban women; * encouraging the availability of pills at pharmacies; and * encouraging the promotion of pills in rural area 26. According to the 1994 ICDS, approximately 2 percent of married women in the country currently use the pill. Given this low base of users, as a first step it is proposed that women in urban areas be targeted for increased pill usage. Specifically, under the project the following expansion strategy will be initiated:
 - 111 - Annex 6 (a) Bids will be invited from social marketing agencies with demonstrated experience to launch a new brand of low priced pills (VND 500 per cycle) in five cities: Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City, Da Nang, Hai Phong, and Hue. (b) Pills will be supplied at no cost and the social marketing agency will be expected to provide the brand name, packaging, distribution to pharmacies and advertising and promotion support. The agency will be given complete autonomy to make decisions on strategy and implementation within agreed budgets. (c) The agency will also be expected to recruit, train and deploy promoters (they must be women) to slums and low income areas in these five cities with the task of oonverting non-users of modem methods to the pill, where conversion will be defined as the user's agreeing to visit a doctor, obtain a prescription and start purchasing pills from the nearest pharmacy (when regulations permit, pills can be delivered to the users home by the agency's delivery system). (d) Promoters will be paid a fixed monthly salary and allowance based on continued usage by the clients they have converted. This allowance will be structured so that it will be possible for the promoter to earn an additional 50 percent of salary per month with reasonable effort. (e) The social marketing agency will be reimbursed for all packaging, distribution, promotion and advertising costs after adjusting for the revenue earned from sales of pill. In addition, a service fee will be paid to the agency to cover part of its administrative costs. (g) The initial contract will be for two years and will be renewed subject to performance; alternatively, new bids will be invited after two years. This annex describes the underlying assumptions that have been utilized to calculate the needed quantities of contraceptive supplies for the years 1997-2002. The calculations were based on contraceptive prevalence and method mix projections that conform to NCPFP goals for the year 2002. Specific details follow. 2. Assumed Prices. (a) Contraceptive pills: US$0.30 per cycle. Annual number of cycles required per woman= 13. (b) Multiload IUDs from China: US$0.75 per unit. Assumed life of RJD: 4.0 years. (c) Norplant: US$25.00 per unit. Assumed life of Norplant: 4.5 years. (d) Injectables: US$1.00 per dose. Four doses per user per year. (Purchase 4.5 doses per woman). 3. CMW of Reproductive Age. An estimate of the number of currently married women of reproductive age (15-49) was provided for 1989 by the census of Viet Nam. The size of the CMW population was projected annually to year 2002 through assumption of a declining growth rate. The annual growth rate (1989-1990) was assumed to be 2.6%, falling to 2.0% in 2001-2002. 4. Contraceptive Prevalence Rate. Minimal change in the contraceptive prevalence rate (CPR) is projected between 1994 and 2002, but the importance of modern methods relative to traditional ones is projected to increase substantially. The CPR will only increase from 65.0%/o to 66.0% whereas the CPR for modern methods will increase from 43.8% to 56.1%. Only a minimal reduction in non-users is assumed (from 35.0% to 34%). 5. Overall Method Mix. Based on the 1994 Inter-Censal Demographic Survey, of current users of family planning, 58% use long-term methods (IUD, female and male sterilization, and Norplant), 10% use short-term methods (pills, condoms, injectables, diaphragm/foam/ jelly), while 30% use typically less-effective traditional methods (periodic abstinence, withdrawal, and others). The method mix is projected to alter such that the mix in 2002 will be 60)% long-term, 25% short-term, and 15% traditional. This is consistent with an increase in the CPR for modern methods from 43.8% to 56.1% over the same time period.
 -114- Annex 7 6. Long-Term Methods. IUDs will continue to be the most prevalent form of long-term family planning in Viet Nam, but their share among long-term methods will decline slightly, from 89% in 1994 to 86% in 2002. New multiload IUDs will be supplied to an estimated 20% of IUD users. The proportion of long-term users with Norplant will increase from 0% to 2% between 1994 to 2002. Full costs are assumed in the costing tables. Female and male sterilization is projected to increase slightly, from 11% to 12% of current users of long-term family planning services. The project will not incur additional costs as a result of this change. 7. Short-Term Methods. Condom-use is currently the most prevalent form of short-term method use in Viet Nam with 63% of the short-term users, following by birth-control pills (33%), injectables (3%), and diaphragm/injectables (1%). Increased reliance on injectables and pills is assumed such that the method mix in 2002 will be: birth control pills (36%), injectables (24%), condoms (39%), and diaphragm (1%). The project will finance both injectalbles and oral contraceptives; condoms and diaphragms will not be supplied. 8.  -130- Annex 11 INDICATIVE LIST OF TOPICS TO BE FINANCED UNDER THE SERVICE DELIVERY MODEL INITIATIVES COMPONENT Model Strengthened Collaborator System 1. The current collaborator system is the principal channel of community- based outreach for tlhe promotion of family planning. However it is in need of strengthening. At present the system consists of a very large number of part-time workers who are paid very small monthly allowances of 15,000 dongs per month (plus incentive payments for recruitment of acceptors of selected methods) and focus almost entirely on the promotion of family planning. 2. A new model system will be tested under component 5, and extended if successful throughout the 15 project provinces under Component 1; it will feature much reduced numbers of collaborators, who will become full-time workers paid higher allowances of 120,000 dongs per month and cover promotion of family health as well as family planning. An imlportant FP function would be the community-based distribution for temporary methods such as pills (resupply) and condoms. The new name of Family Health Worker will be given to these workers. The outline of the new model system is as follows: 3. Forty five communes will be selected within the 15 project provinces for testing the new model system. Twenty two will be located in remote mountainous areas or isolated islands; eighteen in the delta regions; and five in midland or mountainous areas falling between the tvvo previous extremes. A community needs assessment/feasibility study will be carried out in each study zone, in order to ensure full community participation, determine local cultural attitudes and values, and assess the existing health infrastructure and referral system. 4. In the remote mountainous/island areas, 7 workers would be selected per commune; in the midland/mountainous areas, 5 workers; and in the delta plains, 3 workers, making up 233 family health workers altogether in the test. Selection criteria would be determined locally on the basis of the community needs assessment and in discussion with the communities. Normally, the most effective workers of this type are those closest in social status, culture, age and experience; they should also be contraceptors themselves. Other important criteria might include sex, literacy or educational level, marital and childbearing status, health training, and appropriate commitment and skills in interpersonal relations. 5. The tasks of the family health workers would be fine-tuned on the basis of the community needs assessment. However a likely minimum package would include:
 - 131 - Annex 11 (a) motivation and recruitment of new FP acceptors and support, counselling and reassurance to continuing users; all supported by adequate quantities of appropriate printed IEC materials which can be left with clients, as well as by mass media messages (b) distribution of contraceptive supplies: using a simple checklist, workers will initiate and resupply clients for short-term temporary methods such as the pill and condoms; the low-dose combined pill would be supplied to women who are breastfeeding or contraindicated for the use of oestrogen; adequate quantities would be provided per visit (for example, six pill packets) in order to reduce the number of visits needed per client; workers with sufficient medical training could also be trained to give injectables (c) follow-up of contraceptive defaulters: workers would regularly follow up both their own clients and those who obtained their method elsewhere (d) promotion and simple services for basic primary health care: workers could promote, follow up on and perhaps provide simple basic care for basic PH-C interventions such as EPI, CDD, growth monitoring and appropriate maternal care; also disease control programs for malaria, TB, iodine deficiency diseases etc. 6. In order to carry out these tasks on a door-to-door basis, workers will be provided where necessary with suitable transport such as bicycles or (in very remote areas with difficult terrain and sparse settlements) motorcycles. 7. Training of the family health workers would be fine-tuned on the basis of the community needs assessments and resulting selection criteria for workers. Generally speaking, the content of training would be kept very simple and concrete, using training techniques appropriate to adults and oriented to the development of practical skills. Training should last for at least 2 weeks, in order to allow adequate time for practical training. Workers would be trained to: (a) provide accurate information on each contraceptive method they offer (pills, condoms, injectables), including its proper use and side effects (b) discuss the advantages of family planning and birth spacing and describe accurately all available methods, their correct use and their side-effects (c) provide advice on how to obtain clinical methods
 -132- Annex 11 (d) discuss the advantages of basic PHC and disease control interventions and programs and provide accurate information on them The training curriculurn would be prepared by revising the latest collaborator curriculum developed with UNFPA support, in order to simply the material and add health topics. 8. Medical back-up for the family health workers will be provided by CHCs. To ensure that this back-up is effective, CHC staff in the study areas will be involved in the planning of the new system and will be trained in technical supervision of the workers. All CHCs in the study zones will be upgraded as necessary to provide good-quality referral and back-up services. 9. The objectives of supervision for the family health workers will be to: provide support and back-up when problems arise; watch for any difficulties; and link the family health worker system effectively to the mainstream FP program and to the health system. As described in Annex 15, a model health post system would be tested in 60 communes in remote mountainous areas in the 15 project provinces, and expanded under Component 1 to all such areas in the 15 project provinces if successful.  -136- Annex 11 Model Approaches for Safe Pregnancy and Safe Motherhood 21. Levels of maternal mortality appear to be anomalously high in Viet Nam, given overall levels of life expectancy and health services. Important facets of matemal health care, such as provision of iron and vitamin A supplements during pregnancy and adequate delivery facilities for both normal and complicated deliveries, need improvement throughout the country, but particularly in remote and underserved areas. These model approaches would seek to improve the well-being of women during pregnancy and delivery in a variety of ways. An initial list of models includes: (a) Reduction of Anaemia and Vitamin A Deficiency: Both anaemia and vitamin A deficiency are very common among Vietnamese women of reproductive age, and still more during pregnancy. They may lead to various obstetric complications and compromise the health of infants born to deficient women. Evaluative studies will be carried out to identify the most successful model strategies for reducing these deficiencies. Such strategies might include, in addition to provision of supplements as a part of prenatal care, dietary supplementation with foods rich in iron and vitamin A, treatment for underlying or resulting diseases (such as malaria and general infections), and counselling and IEC on good nutritional practices. (b) Safe Home Deliveries: Over forty percent of deliveries in Viet Nam still take place at home, and 27 percent occur without assistance from any health staff. Nearly two thirds of communes are without a secondary midwife. Thus approaches need to be designed for improving home delivery practices. An initial survey would be conducted to identify and investigate any harmful practices, and to examine reasons for delivering at home and/or without trained medical staff in attendance. On the basis of the study results, model approaches would be designed and tested for improving current home delivery practices and increasing utilization of health facilities and staff for deliveries. Management of High-Risk Pregnancy and Complications: About 15 percent of deliveries world-wide suffer from obstetric complications (haemorrhage, sepsis, eclampsia, obstructed labour) that are potentially life-threatening and require specialized management and facilities. Various model approaches would be designed and tested for improving access to and utilization of appropriate facilities. These might include establishment of "maternity waiting houses" near District or Provincial hospitals for women known to be at high-risk of complications, programs to promote private practice in isolated rural areas (as
 -137- Annex 1l above), and programs to establish or improve systems for emergency referral and transport in obstetric emergencies. Model Approaches for IUD, Pregnancy Termination and RTI Services 22. Levels of IUD use and pregnancy termination are very high in Viet Nam; one third of married women are fitted with an IUD and the average number of terminations per woman is estimated at 2.5. Likewise, RTIs are known to be extremely prevalent among Vietnamese women, though the precise rate has never been measured. All are interconnected, in that RTIs may complicate both IUD insertion and pregnancy termination, and also result from either procedure if sterile conditions are not achieved; moreover, IUDs are often in practice the only modern contraceptive method available to Vietnamese women and if they are unacceptable for any reason (including RTIs), termination may be the only practical alternative or may become necessary through the failure of the rhythm method or withdrawal. All require improvement in service quality or access to effective treatment, and the prevalence rates of RTIs and termination, at least, need to be reduced. Model approaches to achieve these aims in all three areas will be developed on the basis of improved data. A. IUD Program Impact Evaluation 23. The IUI) has for decades been and still is the dominant modem contraceptive method in Viet Nam. Many clinical studies on this method have been conducted, but no evalLiation of its program impact. Therefore as a first step, a study of national scope would be conducted to assess the acceptability of the IUD among Vietnamese women, the common problems encountered by acceptors and users, the training needs of service providers, and how well equipped facilities are to handle problems and complications. This study would have four parts: (a) Review of IUD Patient Records: a national representative sample of IUD client records will be reviewed from all levels of facility where lUDs are provided. Data will be extracted on: demographic characteristics of acceptors; selection criteria used for IUD users; the client follow-up schedule., complaints and problems reported by clients; how these were managed; level and patterns of method failure; and main reasons for discontinuation. (b) Interviews with Current and Past IUD Users: a representative sample of past and current IUD users whose records were reviewed in part (1) of the survey will be interviewed. Current users will be questioned on: what and
 -138- Annex 11 who motivated them to accept an IUD; what was their experience of insertion; what were provider attitudes and care; whether or not they received accurate information and effective support; how often they have been followed up; whether they have any complaints or complications; how satisfied they are with the method; and whether they would recommend a friend or relative to use the IUD. Past users will be questioned on their experience with the IUD: in particular whether they had complaints or complications, were happy or not with the method, why they discontinued, whether they switched to another method, which method they changed to, and whether they would recommend a friend or relative to use an IUD. (c) Questionnaires Administered to HUD Providers: Service providers would be surveyed to examine: their knowledge of and attitudes to the IUD and other contraceptive methods; their training in insertion and removal; their current level of skill in counselling, client selection for IUD use, insertion and removal techniques. In addition, focus-group discussions with groups of providers would be conducted to elicit in depth their attitudes and beliefs about the IUD in an informal setting. (d) Focus-Group Discussions with Women in General: Wide-ranging focus- group discussions would be carried out with unselected groups of women in the community, with the aim of eliciting: general attitudes to the IUD; whether they are correctly informed about the IUD; what are the common myths and misconceptions about the IUD; and what are the common myths and misconceptions about other methods. 24. On the basis of results from this study, model approaches, protocols and interventions would be developed and tested to improve IUD acceptability and service quality: for example, through standardization of state-of-the-art IUD insertion and removal techniques, follow-up care and RTI treatment; fine-tuning of selection and screening criteria for IUD use; corresponding refresher training and improved pre-service training; better supervision of providers; provision of appropriate IEC materials and programs, etc. B. Evaluation of Pregnancy Termination Services 25. Pregnancy termination has been made widely available in Viet Nam with the intention of providing safe back-up services in the event of contraceptive failure. Current levels of menstrual regulation and abortion are however much above expected back-up needs in a situation of widespread access to modern contraception and need to be
 -139 - Annex 11 reduced. Again, a number of clinical studies on this subject have been carried out, but there is still a need for an assessment of the causes and program implications of the current high termination rates. Therefore a national study will be conducted using both institutional-level and community-level data. Its aims will be to establish the level of pregnancy termination, to determine the reasons for seeking pregnancy termination, and the consequences of current levels and patterns of termination. The study will be composed of three parts, as follows: (a) Study of Service Records: From a representative sample of termination client records, the following data will be collected: demographic characteristics of women seeking termination; reasons for opting for termination; contraceptive history. (b) Study of Service Providers: A sample of providers will be surveyed on aspects of service quality at all levels of facility where terminations are done, including questions on: what kind of pre-termination and post- termination counselling they offer, with particular attention to minimizing or preventing repeat abortions through appropriate contraception; their training and skill levels in termination techniques; schedules of follow-up care; treatment of RTIs; and main complications and problems encountered. The sample survey would aim to collect reliable data on the incidence and patterns of pregnancy termination, including service location and cost of the procedure to the client (this latter to be supplemented also by data from MOH on the cost of providing the service). The focus-group discussions would explore community perceptions of and attitudes to pregnancy termination. 26. On the basis of results from this study, model approaches, protocols and interventions would be developed and tested to reduce levels of pregnancy terminati n and improve service quality: for example, in addition to improved access to a wide ra ge

Although RTIs are universally acknowledged to be a major reproductive health problem in Viet Nam, there is a severe lack of data on RTI incidence, prevalence, patterns and causes.  -151- Annex 13 PROJECT MANAGEMENT ARRANGEMENTS A. Background 1. NCPFP set up a national level Project Steering Committee (PSC) and Project Unit (PU) in January 1994. In addition, provincial level project units were also established in the five first-phase provinces. The PSC and PU worked closely with the Bank missions in project preparation and design, thus initiating the project management structure at an early stage. B. Organization 2. The central project management organization will have three layers: * a Ministerial level--Project Steering Committee (PSC); * a Director level-- Executive Comrnittee (EC); and * a working level--Project Management Unit (PMU). 3. The SC will be chaired by the Chairman of the NCPFP, and its members will consist of the Vice-Ministers of the Ministry of Planning and Investment (WPI), Ministry of Finance (MOF), State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) and Ministry of Health (MOH). The EC will be composed of the eight department directors of NCPFP. In addition, a Director will be assigned as a standing member of EC and will serve as full- time Project Director. Steering Committee Chairman (NCPFP) 4 Members (MPI, SBV, MOF, MOH) Executive Committee Chairman (NCPFP) 8 Directors of Line Departments of NCPFP 1 Standing Members as Project Director Project Management Unit Expert Task Force

In addition, the PMU will hire local consultants as needed to form task forces to assist project management in special areas. These task forces will work directly under the leadership of the central Project Director. The key staff positions identified in the NCPFP Project Management Unit are those of Director, Task Manager, Lead Civil Works Officer, Lead Procurement Officer And Lead Disbursement Officer. In the 15 project provinces, provincial PUs will be established and which will consist of a Manager and three staff. | Proj cManaginn UMat t NCPFP e I r* Mffinager a ng/Logitics(1) ||Acccentng (1) | C. Functions & Operation 5. The Steering Committee will be the highest level of decision-making during project implementation. It will meet regularly every three months to discuss various aspects of project supervision, and to make decisions on relevant policies and strategies for proper project implementation. The main function of the SC will be to foster coordination am.ong NCPFP and the other relevant agencies namely, MPI, MOF, SBV, and MOH. 6. The Executive Committee will play an important role in mobilizing the policy and technical resources within NCPFP by involving the line departments in project implementation. Each department would be assigned one component/sub-component, for example, the IEC Department will be responsible for the dEC component, and the Family Planning Coordination Department will be responsible forcthe family health service delivery component. Each Department will then be responsible for ensuring that the project fits into the overall plan to meet national objectives and resolve any conflicts that may arise between project and program goals and objectives. The EC will therefore meet every month to review implementation during the course of the project. 7. The horizontal coordination among all the line departments will be the responsibility of the Project Director and the Project Management Unit under his leadership. The PMU will prepare the annual working plan and progress report for review

 -154- Annex 14 PROJECT MONITORING, EVALUATION AND SUPERVISION 1. Projects in the social sectors are often plagued by a lack of reliable baseline data as well as weak monitoring and evaluation systems. Bank projects, in particular, have traditionally focused on project inputs and accountability issues, rather than on project outputs and impact indicators in terms of reductions in fertility, improvements in health status for individuals, or the performance of the health services. This makes it impossible to assess the impact of the proposed interventions on the population. Current Status of Population and Demographic Statistics in Viet Nam 2. The Government of Viet Nam has become increasingly aware of the need for regular and reliable population and demographic statistics for formulating and monitoring its population policies and for other development planning purposes. Two population and housing censuses (in 1979 and in 1989) have been conducted since reunification in 1975. Another census is planned for 1999. These censuses contain information on childbearing, childhood and adult mortality, and other key indicators that we have selected for measuring the progress of the project. Disaggregation to the province level and for specific sub-groups (ethnic minorities, married women of reproductive age, etc.) of the population is possible for some of the indicators. 3. The General Statistics Office (GSO) also prepares a time series of national and sub-national population and demographic estimates for use by the Ministry of Planning and Investment and other agencies. However, the range and detail of the estimates it currently prepares is very limited, and is insufficient to meet the needs of the Population and Family Health Project. 4. Civil registration of births and deaths, which has its legal origins in a government directive in 1961, takes place at the commune level. It is widely recognized, however, that there is very severe under-registration of births and deaths, particularly in rural areas, as well as frequently delayed registration. Registrars are unsure about their registration duties, and are hampered by lack of training, lack of materials, and lack of incentive to perform these duties. Large Survey Efforts 5. The Viet Nam Demographic and Health Survey (VNDHS) was carried out in 1988, the first such assessment of demographic and health status since the implementation of population and family planning programs in the early 1 960s. The nationally-representative sample survey was carried out by the National Committee for Population and Family Planning (NCPFP), with financial support from UNFPA. A total of 4,807 households and 4,172 eligible women aged 15 to 49 years old were interviewed to collect data on fertility, family planning, and a few indicators of child and maternal health.
 - 155 - Annex 14 6. A second demographic survey was carried out more recently in 1994 by the General Statistical Office (GSO), with financial support from UNFPA. The survey, the Vietnam 1994 Intercensal Demographic Survey, was conducted in order to update information on human reproduction, infant and child mortality, contraceptive use, and maternal and child care. More than 13,000 households and 10,490 ever-married women between the ages of 15 and 50 were interviewed. Estimates are representative of the population at three levels: national, urban/rural, and for seven geographical regions. Status of Family Planning and Family Health Service Statistics 7. Family planning and facility-related health statistics are also routinely collected at various levels of the Vietnamese system. The organization and control of data collection and compilation are highly decentralized and have their roots in some 10,000 communes, the lowest level of administrative units Two streams of data processing occur in the system, which can be simplified as follows. Firs1, the commune family-planning collaborator reports information on acceptors, method mix, and other factors to the Commune Population and Family Planning Board (CPFPB), where it is summarized and then sent in turn to the District (DCPFP), to the Province (PCPFP), and to the National level (NCPFP). Second, the commune family-planning collaborator reports the same information to the Commune Health Center (CHC), where it is combined with other information on CHC ifacility usage (for family planning as well as other health concerns). Data from mobile team efforts are also incorporated. These reports are compiled and sent in turn to the district health services (DHS), provincial health bureau (PHB), and National (MOH) levels. At the appropriate levels, infbrmation on services provided at polyclinics, provincial hospitals, and other facilities is added in. 8. A number of problems are evident with this system. The foundation of the data collection system is the collaborator or CHC-level worker. Collaborators are generally unpaid volunteers, with low or no levels of basic training and frequently only low levels of basic skills. The CHC-level workers, while of higher qualification than the collaborators, are often lacking the basic skills that are required for data collection and reporting. 9. System inefficiencies are evident throughout the country. Data are almost entirely manually compiled and processed at all stages, increasing the probability of introducing bias into the statistics. Furthermore, since workers in both the NCPFP and the MOH stream are compiling family-planning information, there is a duplication of effort. Given these constraints and in the absence of a thorough evaluation of the service statistics, the data are of unknown but questionable quality. Evaluation of the Viet Nam Population and Family Health Project 10. Given this background, the Viet Nam Population and Farnily Health Project will implement four basic strategies to monitor and evaluate the Project.
 -156 - Annex 14 Namely, (a) Conduct of three major surveys (baseline, mid-term review, and final evaluation) for the purposes of project evaluation, particularly to measure the project impact indicators which have been selected for the project. (b) Conduct of three major studies (baseline, mid-term review, and final evaluation) also for the purposes of project evaluation. These studies will measure indicators of project impact for components of family planning and family health that cannot be readily measured using a population-based survey sample. These studies will mostly require evaluation of particular components based on facility records. (c) Conduct of special surveys and studies to evaluate the special needs and appropriate strategies for meeting those needs for the major ethnic minority populations. (d) Management Information System (MIS) efforts. This will include strengthening the use of computers for data gathering and analysis at national and provincial levels, strengthening of managers' capacity for using information for planning, prioritizing and monitoring population and family planning activities through training availability of necessary resources at levels. 11. The data sources which will be utilized to calculate a full matrix of input, intermediate, and impact indicators have been selected for the Viet Nam Population and Family Health Project for national, provincial, and lower levels. Within this matrix, ten key indicators have been selected to measure project impact and achievement. In general, most of the key indicators can be calculated from special surveys that have been planned at three points in the project cycle. A few will require conduct of specialized studies of routinely-collected information that is available from CHC's and from family planning workers. Strengthening of the MIS efforts will facilitate this task. Project Surveys 12. Three major surveys will be implemented as part of the Viet Nam Population and Family Health Project at various times in the project cycle. The first, to be conducted before project activities begin, will provide baseline data. A mid-term review will occur towards the middle of the project. A final evaluation of the project will be conducted at completion of the project. The World Bank requires conduct of these three surveys as part of its agreement with the Government of Viet Nam. The National Committee for Population and Family Planning (or an agent thereof) will be responsible for the overall implementation of the survey, including sample design, preparation of survey instruments, testing, training, field work, data processing, and
 -157 - Annex 14 analysis. A written report on the major findings for each of the key indicators is required for each of the surveys. 13. All three surveys will be national-level, population-based sample surveys. Over- sampling of the ethnic minoriity populations in the 15 Project provinces will be carried out. These surveys will assess the family planning and family health status of the population, with particular emphasis on the ten key indicators that have been selected for the Project. 14. In addition to collecting data in order to calculate the key indicators, special supplements to the three data collection efforts should address particular components of the project. For instance, a module on knowledge, attitudes, and practice of contraception would help to monitor and evaluate the IEC component of the project. A module on service delivery would address whether contraceptives that are procured by the project ultimately reach women in the villages.

Findings; of the Baseline Survey Exercise: Most ethnic groups are known from census and survey data to be poor, ill-educated and isolated. It is therefore hardly surprising that thieir demographic profile is unfavourable. However the proximate determinants of their fertility and mortality levels and patterns have been little studied. A first step in the design of any special strategy is therefore a set of baseline surveys and participative baseline studies (see Annex 14). A model exercise of this kind was conducted as part of project preparation in Dac Lac province. 5. The major findings of the participative studies conducted in Dac Lac among a number of minority groups were as follows: (a) family planning, modem contraception and modern health care appear to be very acceptable to minority women, couples and communities (b) Government and health workers are not always in touch with community attitudes and interests in the health and family planning sectors and communications between program staff and communities need to be improved (c) there is considerable unsatisfied demand for temporary methods of contraception in many minority communities, particularly pills and injectables (d) health facilities in minority areas were often dilapidated and poorly equipped and supplied (e) there is a severe deficiency of good-quality IEC materials and activities in minority communes (f) there is a large reservoir of interested and motivated minority community members who could be tapped for extension, outreach or community-based distribution work for family planning and health (g) there is a need for refresher training for health and FP staff, particularly for family planning, with emphasis on counselling skills and up-to-date knowledge of modern contraceptive methods

In line with the above, field observations in Lau Cai during project preparation identified the following major problems in the delivery of primary health care and family planning in remote mountainous areas: (a) long travel distances between villages and CHCs, resulting in low utilisation of CHCs and heavy dependence on DHC mobile teams to provide services (b) serious understaffling of CHCs, with many empty facilities used only as premises for visiting DHC teams (c) serious shortages of minority health workers, due to low educational levels among rninority groups (d) low skill levels among minority health workers, for the same reason 7. Outline of a Special Strategy for Health and FP Service Delivery in Remote Minority Areas: Based on the above findings, plus available information from other sources, the outline of a set of special strategies for delivery of health and family planning services in minority areas that are remote and mountainous, and hence isolated and underserved at the present moment, has been developed for introduction and testing under the project. Details will be refined on the basis of the full findings from the baseline surveys and studies to be conducted as a first step, but a preliminary set of possible interventions has been identified. Its principal approach is to adapt the standard Viet Nam model of service delivery to the special needs of remote areas and minority cultures by upgrading, strengthening and expanding outreach, access and community-level or community-based services and promotive activities. Major features are as follows: (a) Adaptation of the CHC Model for Remote Mountainous Areas: Since larger in-patient CHC facilities which can do deliveries will not be utilised in remote mountainous areas, only small outpatient facilities will be provided in such areas under Component I of the project (as well as under the National Health Support Project). (b) Establishment of Health Posts: A model health post system would be tested under Component 5 in 60 communes in remote mountainous areas in
 -174 - Annex 15 the 15 project provinces, and expanded under Component I to all such areas in the 15 project provinces if successful. For a commune to be eligible for coverage by the system, it must fulfil the following criteria: (i) the CHC must have at least 3 health staff (ii) the CHC must be at least 4 hours walking distance from the nearest DHC (iii) there must be strong commitment from the Provincial People's Committee A health post would be set up in one village in each commune. It would consist of two small rooms, one of which would be a consultation room/office and the other a bedroom. Basic furniture, medical equipment, a selection of essential drugs, and a bicycle for household visiting would be supplied. The health post would be staffed by one of the CHC health workers, on either a rotational basis or as a permanent assignment, according to the choice of the workers. The health worker in residence would provide basic IEC and services for MCH/FP, including the distribution of appropriate contraceptives and some minor curative care. In the separate new collaborator (family health worker) system to be also tested (see below) the health post could be staffed by the new family health worker. (c) Establishment of Family Health Workers: Remote mountainous areas and minority areas would participate in the new collaborator (renamed family health worker) model system to be tested under Component 5 and extended to cover the 15 project provinces if successful under Component 1; out of the total 45 communes selected for testing, 22 would be in remote mountainous areas and another 5 in midland and mountainous areas that are not considered remote. In remote areas, 7 full-time family health workers would be recruited per commune (compared to 3 in delta communes and 5 in the midland/mountainous areas) and each would be given a bicycle to facilitate household visiting. If both the health post and the family health worker systems are successful, the health posts could be staffed by family health workers as an alternative to CHC staff. (d) Additional Transport for DHC Outreach: Under Component 1, DHCs in remote mountainous areas would be provided with extra motorcycles (and in thie Mekong delta, motor boats) in order to enhance their outreach capabilities. The vehicles would be used by the DHC mobile teams for EPI, FP and control of endemic diseases. The project would also finance
 -175 - Annex 15 maintenance and operating costs for the vehicles. The impact of this additional transport would be evaluated at the end of the project and continued under regular health/FP budgets if judged essential to full functioning of the DHC mobile teams. (e) Special Training Strategy for Remote Mountainous Areas: Because of the lack of local minority candidates with adequate minimum educational qualificaltions (completion of high school), health staff in these areas are at least 80 percent Kinh. Even so, there is an acute shortage of CHC health workers, with more than 50 percent of the approximately 500 communes in the remcte mountainous areas of the 15 project provinces currently lacking any resident CHC staff. Such CHCs must be staffed by a seconded DHC worker. Skills of minority health workers, where they exist, also often need improveiment. Thus special strategies for pre-service and in-service training will be implemented in the 15 project provinces in order to both increase minority worker numbers and upgrade skills of existing minority staff, as follows: (i) Pre-Service Special Training: About 300 minority health workers with below-standard educational qualifications would be recruited and employed by the local CPFPB, and trained as "family health workers" to serve in CHCs. They would receive a short basic on- the-job training course of about one month at the local DCH, plus two supplementary courses of the same length to follow later once the workers were in service. In addition, they would receive in- service refresher training of 2 days every 4 months at the local DHC. Those who showed promise could later take the regular primary midwife pre-service course at the provincial secondary medical school and then be upgraded to the level of primary midwife. (ii) In-Service Special Training: Frequent refresher training would be provided to the approximately 500 minority workers stationed in 'CHCs in the remote mountainous areas, in order to upgrade and maintain their skills. The training schedule would comprise four short courses per year of about two days each at the local DHC. (iii) Special Training Methodologies: All the in-service and pre- service training described above would take place at the DHC in order to facilitate attendance. DHCs would be provided with the necessary teaching aids. Training methodology and materials would be adapted to lower educational levels through: an emphasis on
 - 176- Annex 15 practical skills and demonstration models; heavy use of pictorial materials; translation of training materials into local minority languages; and special training of DHC trainers in the use of these special methodologies and materials. A reference manual adapted to this modified training approach will be developed and provided to all minority CHC workers (including family planning workers) in remote mountainous areas throughout the country, except for the National Health Support Project provinces where it would be provided under that project's financing. (g) Special Family Planning Approach for Minority Groups: The project as a whole responds to the findings above through support of increased access to and promotion of modem temporary methods such as pills and injectables, as well as improved models of IUD. However, special approaches will be designed and implemented to adapt family planning services to the particular conditions, needs and preferences of minority communities. This will be done after the results of the baseline surveys and studies are available for guidance, and will be based on them. It is expected that these special approaches will include: (i) emphasis on promotion and provision of modem temporary methods (ii) custom-designed and high-quality IEC programs and materials for at least the largest minority groups (iii) particular attention to counselling, community participation and community-based activities and programs.
