It is based on the premise that spending on population/FP should reach a level of US$0.6 by the year 2000, the goal which has been approved by the Prime Minister. If the budget were to remain static in real terms, it might increase to around US$58 million by the year 2002. 9. According to MOH projections, the total national health budget for the year 2002 will reach 12,625 billion dong, or US$1.26 billion. If a more conservative projection is followed of an annual growth rate of only 8 percent, the 2002 health budget would amount to 4,205 billion dong, or US$420 million. This more conservative assumption will be adopted for this analysis. C. Recurrent Cost Implications 10. Implications for the National Population/FP Budget: The annual recurrent cost burden on the national population/FP budget generated by the project will amount to around US$4.5 million for contraceptive commodities plus logistics costs. Maintenance costs would add another US$ just under 450,000, making up US$5 million in total. This would amount to about 8.5% of the projected population/FP budget for 2002, a significant but sustainable amount. 11. Taking a wider perspective, however, it makes sense to assess the entire annual contraceptive coimmodity burden that would require to be financed at the end of the project. As mentioned above, this is projected at US$7.5 million, exclulding condoms, by 2002. Thus, contraceptive commodity and logistic costs alone would amount to around 13 percent of the projected 2002 total budget. 12. This scale of resource allocation for contraceptive supplies is not excessive by the standards of family planning programs worldwide and therefore should be sustainable by the Government of Viet Nam even if all these supplies were to be financed by Government itself and provided free of charge through public programs. In fact, a proportion of users already obtain their contraceptive supplies from the private sector and the importance of bot:h the private sector and social marketing is likely to grow
 -180 - Annex 16 substantially during the life of the project. A program of charges for public program users is also planned to be introduced during the second half of the project. It is moreover very likely that donor suppo:rt to contraceptive supplies would continue to be significant after the year 2000, outside the umbrella of the project itself The sustainability of the expanded contraceptive costs should therefore present no major problems. 13. Implications for the National Health Budget: The annual recurrent cost burden on the national health budget generated by the project will amount to around US$2.7 million, made up of US$2.25 million for drugs and medical supplies, and US$450,000 for maintenance. This would amount to 0.64 percent of a conservative projection of the national health budget for 2002, which is a negligible amount. 14. Incremental costs on this scale should not by themselves be difficult to sustain. However, again it makes sense to adopt a broader perspective, and consider the additional impact of the National Health Support Project and any further extension of upgrading packages throughout the country. The National Health Support Project would provide a similar upgrading package over the same period to another 15 provinces, raising total coverage to more than half the country. However the two projects together would still only raise incremental recurrent costs for the 30 provinces together to around US$5.4 million or less than 1.5 percent of the national health budget. 15. Taking a still wider view, if the provincial upgrading package should succeed in improving service quality and utilisation, Government might perhaps consider a similar upgrading program in the country's remaining provinces. At most, however, the additional recurrent cost burden from a similar investment program in the rest of the country would about double that generated by the two projects. Thus annual costs of essential drugs and maintenance of upgraded facilities and equipment for CHCs and DHCs for the entire country would consume only around 3 percent of the national health budget. It does not appear, therefore, that the upgrading of Viet Nam's PHC services could create any major problem of sustainability.
 -181- Annex 17 OUTLINE OF THE IMPLEMENTATION VOLUME 1. The "Implementation Volume" is a follow-up document to the Staff Appraisal Report. It is intended to serve as a detailed guide to day-to-day implementation of the project and will be prepared in its final form by the NCPFP itself between negotiations and project effectiveness. An "implementation volume" consists basically of a compilation of all usefiul background maLterials put together in the course of project preparation, together with a summary time-bound implementation plan for the entire project and detailed time- bound annual implementation plans for at least the first year or two of activities. It is better viewed not as a single document, but as a set of files containing all necessary reference materials as well as a basic blueprint for implementation planning. 2. What follows is an indicative outline of the contents of the Implementation Volume, for use as a guide to its preparation. The Summary Implementation Plan for the Project 3. The core of this implementation plan would be a timetable of major project activities, along the lines of a Gantt chart, Pert chart or Computerized Project Management chart. For the summary plan, time need only be shown in blocks of months, say quarters of a year, and activities in each component of the project can be summarized in broad categories. This plan timetable should be kept permanently on the Project Management Unit's computer system and updated continuously by management and MIS staff. Print-outs could then be produced at regular intervals, say every six months, for information and use by other project staff. To supplement the timetable, a text would be added describing the major features of the plan, together with any notes needed on details of its content. 4. The Implementation Volume itself would contain only the first plan timetable and text produced at the beginning of the project, which would set the format to be used. An indicative example follows. The latest print-out would then be included in each six- monthly progress report submitted to IDA (see Annex 14). The Detailed Annual Implementation Plans 5. The core of the annual implementation plan would be a set of timetables for each year of the project, covering all activities planned under each component of the project, again in the form of a Gaantt chart, Pert chart, Computerized Project Management chart etc. Again, the timetables should be supplemented by as detailed a text as is necessary. 6. For planning purposes, the timetables should be prepared at the end of each project or fiscal year (whichever is more convenient) for rolling time-periods of two years, i.e., a plan/timetable for the first two years should be prepared at the beginning of the project;
 -182 - Annex 17 then at the end of the first year, the plan/timetable for the second year should be revised in the light of the achievements of the first year and a plan/timetable for the third year added; then at the beginning of the third year the plan/timetable for the second year should be revised and a plan/timetable for the fourth year added; and so on. 7. Again, these plans/timetables should be permanently kept on the PMU computer and updated continuously by management and MIS staff. Only the first two-year plan/timetable should be included in the Implementation Volume for reference, and to set the format. Print-outs should then be produced at regular intervals, say once or twice a year, for information and use by other project staff. For six-monthly progress reports to be submitted to IDA, a year's time-slice should be produced and included in the report, showing the plan/timetable for the previous six months and following six months. doc.repnme: Viet Nam - Population and Family Health Project
doc.abstracts: The overall purpose of the Population and Family Health Project is to support the strengthening and revitalization of the family health and family planning sector, thereby improving the health status of the population and bringing a further reduction in fertility and population growth. The project will operate at two levels, the first national and the second in a selected group of15 provinces. The project's objectives are: a) to increase utilization of family planning and related family health services; b) to improve the quality and range of family planning and related family health services; c) to enhance the National Committee for Population and Family Planning's (NCPFP) management, planning and policy formulation capabilities; and d) to expand the knowledge base on which policy and technical guidelines would be founded. For the selected 15 provinces, the focus will be on strengthening of the Primary Health Care (PHC) system at commune and district levels, with a particular emphasis on Maternal and Child Health (MCH) and family planning services. The project consists of five components, of which four are national in scope and focused on family planning and the fifth covers the primary health care system (commune and district-level). These components consist of: service delivery; information, education and communication; contraceptive supplies, family planning management and institutional development; and service delivery model initiative.
